meaning_mnemonic: This looks a bit like a waiter walking toward you with a platter in their hands... but wait. It's only half of a waiter. It's a <radical>one sided</radical> waiter!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>oversee</radical>.

A thread goes through the ground. It traces your <radical>lineage</radical>. You follow the thread all the way back through many generations, to find out your lineage involves Genghis Khan. Feel the thread and the dirt in your hand and actually trace the lineage.

Poor turtles. We don't like them here. This is a <radical>turtle shell</radical>. See the shell with just a tail remaining? It's the only thing we didn't remove off the turtle. It's just a shell with a tail, so basically it's just a turtle shell.

This kind of looks like big (大), which I think you'll remember you learned by pretending this was a big guy. This big guy, however, has a funny leg... a peg leg. That makes him a <radical>pirate</radical>. Also, his arms are in the "YARRRR" position.
See the rolling <radical>hills</radical> with the road going off into the background to another hill? That's why this is the hills radical.
A <radical>demon</radical> on a <radical>jet</radical> is pretty <kanji>alluring</kanji>. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>alluring</kanji> demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. <reading>Me</reading>at (み). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> hits the <radical>sun</radical>, where you're in <radical>prison</radical> with a <radical>spoon</radical> trying to catch some of it before it starts to <kanji>dry up</kanji>. Being in prison on the sun means your <kanji>thirst</kanji> is truly great, and this spoon will help you quench it when the tsunami comes.
reading_mnemonic: This method of quenching your <kanji>thirst</kanji> reminds you of being in a <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>wa</reading>sh (かわ). The water pours over you in waves, and you're stuck inside a metal cage. Totally the same thing as a car wash, right?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>lineage</radical> radical and the <kanji>lineage</kanji> kanji are the same. Sometimes this kanji can also mean <kanji>system</kanji>. I guess a lineage is a kind of system, if you think about it.
reading_mnemonic: You trace your <kanji>lineage</kanji> back through your whole family <kanji>system</kanji> and realize every single relative loved <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい). Most of them were cake bakers too!

meaning_mnemonic: You meet a <radical>woman</radical> from another <radical>clan</radical> under the rising <radical>sun</radical> to prepare for <kanji>marriage</kanji>. Your clan and her clan are standing together as the two of you watch the sun rise together.
reading_mnemonic: For the <kanji>marriage</kanji> to be official, you need to wait for a <reading>con</reading>dor (こん) to appear. If it doesn't show up before the sun goes down again, the marriage was a failure. You have to try again tomorrow with a different woman.

meaning_mnemonic: On a <radical>scooter</radical> running in one <radical>direction</radical> is a <radical>gun</radical>-toting <radical>child</radical>. This is a terribly dangerous situation, but to the child it is just <kanji>play</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Everything is <kanji>play</kanji> for <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう), even if it's a terrible, scary, not good situation like this one.

meaning_mnemonic: Traveling in the <radical>direction</radical> of the ocean, you take a <radical>gun</radical> and shoot a <radical>crab</radical>, then stick a <kanji>flag</kanji> in the beach and claim it as your own. The crab was the only thing standing in the way of you conquering the area. Now that the flag is in the ground, no one can dispute who it belongs to.
reading_mnemonic: To make sure that no one removes your <kanji>flag</kanji>, you lock it to one of the lifeguard posts and you throw away the <reading>key</reading> (き). Since no one will have the key to unlock the flag, no one will be able to remove it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is being <radical>call</radical>ed on to <radical>boil</radical> the earth by <kanji>illuminating</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: The person who calls the sun asking it to <kanji>illuminate</kanji> the earth is the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). It's very specifically the Shougun's responsibility to make sure the earth is illuminated every morning.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>soul</radical> of a <radical>person</radical> has a <radical>hook</radical> that can make them <kanji>pleasant</kanji>. When you see, hear, or feel something pleasant, can't you feel that hook pressing into the middle of your body?
reading_mnemonic: If you want to feel this <kanji>pleasant</kanji> feeling just look at a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい). Kayaks are the most pleasant boats in the world. Feel that pleasant feeling in your chest just from reading about kayaks in this mnemonic right now.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're a <radical>one-sided</radical> paper <radical>anti</radical> (someone against one-sided paper), then you should bind all those one-sided papers into an <kanji>edition</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The first <kanji>edition</kanji> you create is a fan fiction all about the adventures of <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. You hated how short and one-sided his story in Star Wars seemed to be, and trying to keep track of it all was really hard. But not anymore!

meaning_mnemonic: Those that can only eat a <radical>part</radical> of a <radical>shellfish</radical> are probably a bit <kanji>poor</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: And since they are <kanji>poor</kanji>, they are getting these shellfish parts from the trash <reading>bin</reading> (びん). It's quite unfortunate.

meaning_mnemonic: If you look for a <radical>leaf</radical> among the <radical>hills</radical> you will notice they are <kanji>scarce</kanji>. The hills have no trees around them, so there are no leaves. The leaves are scarce here on the hills.
reading_mnemonic: Still looking for a leaf, you determine that they are far too <kanji>scarce</kanji> to find here. Just before you give up, you discover a giant <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball. As you pick it up, another one comes thundering down the hill knocking over a tiny tree.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>scooter</radical> with a <radical>mohawk</radical>, now that's the most <kanji>suitable</kanji> hairstyle you could ever think of for a scooter!
reading_mnemonic: You want this <kanji>suitable</kanji> hairstyle for your scooter too, and luckily you're a <reading>techie</reading> (てき), so it's easy for you to install one.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Beforehand</radical>, to buy a <radical>geoduck</radical>, you have to go to the bank to <kanji>deposit</kanji> enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy one! They're expensive, after all.
reading_mnemonic: You go to the bank to make the <kanji>deposit</kanji>, and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo. Now you can't even see, let alone make the deposit.

meaning_mnemonic: If you do <radical>yoga</radical> <radical>correct</radical>ly, you will not only <kanji>prolong</kanji> your body but your life!
reading_mnemonic: You can <kanji>prolong</kanji> your life with correct yoga techniques, but unfortunately, if you ever stop doing yoga after you've started this prolonging process, it will just <reading>en</reading>d (えん) suddenly.

meaning_mnemonic: Whenever all the <radical>feathers</radical> start <radical>stand</radical>ing, you know it's time for <kanji>the next</kanji> day. Once the day comes to its end, all feathers start standing up like clockwork.
reading_mnemonic: With <kanji>the next</kanji> day approaching and all feathers standing up, you get ready to drink your usual liter of <reading>yolk</reading> (よく). Yes, you heard that right.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>servant</radical> holding a <radical>gun</radical> sits on the <radical>ground</radical> to <radical>see</radical> if he can find something to <kanji>look at</kanji>. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers.
reading_mnemonic: You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man <reading>Ran</reading>dy (らん) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, <kanji>look at</kanji> this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>soul</radical> will <radical>cross</radical> through your body and into the <radical>net</radical> of your <radical>clothes</radical> so that you'll be hit with <kanji>nostalgia</kanji> when you wear them again. Nostalgia for all the things that happened every single time you wore those clothes.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>nostalgia</kanji> ties <reading>knots</reading> (なつ) in your stomach and your chest. Even if the memories and feelings weren't particularly bad, there's something about the wistful feeling of nostalgia that knots up your insides.

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical>, put them on this <radical>turtle shell</radical>, and <kanji>push</kanji> push push! Push the turtle right on out of there.
reading_mnemonic: You're trying to <kanji>push</kanji> this turtle out so you can use the shell for your new <reading>o</reading>bi (お). You keep seeing other people wearing turtle shell patterns on their obi, but you're going to go a step further. You're going to MAKE your obi out of actual turtle shells! You just have to push this darn turtle out first.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> <radical>pirate</radical> jumps from a tree and attacks you by hitting you with a <kanji>pillow</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: As he hits you with his <kanji>pillow</kanji> he makes a demand: "Give me your <reading>Mac cooler</reading> (まくら). He wants the device that cools down your Mac computer.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> knocks a <radical>cleat</radical> off a <radical>child</radical> and the shoe begins to <kanji>float</kanji> away in the water. This child was just out playing soccer, minding his own business, when the tsunami crashed in and knocked his cleats off his feet. Now the cleat is floating away with the tsunami.
reading_mnemonic: While you <kanji>float</kanji> in the water, an <reading>u</reading>ni (う) jabs into your foot. “<reading>Uwa</reading>aa~ (うわ)” you cry. That uni really hurts. They’re all spikey and painful and junk. “Uwaaaa~”

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> rips a <radical>flag</radical> off your house in the <radical>rain</radical>, causing a <kanji>leak</kanji> where it was ripped out. The rain and the tsunami combined just tore the flag right off your house. The force was so strong that it actually removed part of the wall, and now you have a leak in your home.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>leak</kanji> is getting worse and worse and so is the tsunami, when you see something outside. It’s a bunch of <reading>roe</reading> (ろう) floating in the waves. Using your quick thinking skills you scoop it up and shove it into the cracks where the water is leaking in. It works like a charm!

meaning_mnemonic: You take some <radical>bamboo</radical> and <radical>attach</radical> it together into a <kanji>token</kanji> of appreciation for your friend. Your friend greatly appreciates this token of friendship.
reading_mnemonic: You hand over the <kanji>token</kanji> but your friend drops it and yells, "You <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ)! I'm allergic to bamboo!"

meaning_mnemonic: You give a <radical>shellfish</radical> to a <radical>lifeguard</radical> to <kanji>purchase</kanji> their services. You think lifeguards are interested in normal money? Come on, they're obviously out there using shellfish for their purchases. It's only natural, given their seaside habitat.
reading_mnemonic: This time you <kanji>purchase</kanji> some <reading>こう</reading>いち goods. You know, since you're such a fan. How else can you show love in this world, if not through purchases? The lifeguard hands over a little haul of こういち plushies and figurines. Nice.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>run</radical> every day and soon you <radical>become</radical> a human that can <kanji>go beyond</kanji> the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast.
reading_mnemonic: To solidify your ability to <kanji>go beyond</kanji> the abilities of other humans, you <reading>etch</reading> (えつ) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate.

kanji_to_vocab_info.meaning: Bitter Enemies In The Same Boat

meaning_mnemonic: When you <radical>eat</radical> you want to see the shape of your <radical>gun</radical> from under a <radical>towel</radical>, so you <kanji>decorate</kanji> your house with them.
reading_mnemonic: If you actually <kanji>decorate</kanji> your house like this it will give people quite a <reading>shock</reading> (しょく). In fact, they might be so shocked they run out of there screaming.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>horse</radical> gets trapped in a small room with a <radical>stool</radical> and an <radical>insect</radical>, and together they create a very <kanji>boisterous</kanji> situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place.
reading_mnemonic: At the height of their <kanji>boisterous</kanji> sounds, there's a sudden, awful CRONCH(!) and you see the <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) of the insect slowly rising out of the room, through the ceiling.

meaning_mnemonic: You fly <radical>north</radical> to the <radical>moon</radical> and break your <kanji>back</kanji> when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact.
reading_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>back</kanji> hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい) form. 

I flew to the moon.
It is there I broke my back.
My back hurts real bad.

meaning_mnemonic: Point some <radical>fingers</radical> at the <radical>sun</radical> and put some others in your <radical>ear</radical> as you sit on a <radical>stool</radical> — now you can have your <kanji>photograph</kanji> taken. This is a glamour <kanji>photo</kanji>, so you have to be in one of these weird, artsy poses for it to come out juuust right.
reading_mnemonic: As you're getting the <kanji>photograph</kanji> taken, the photographer tells you to say <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ). He says it's like saying cheese but more effective. Satsuki!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>next</radical> <radical>plate</radical> is the one you will <kanji>steal</kanji>. This one would be too obvious, better wait for the next one.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>steal</kanji> this plate from a <reading>とう</reading>きょう restaurant, so after you steal it, picture yourself running through the streets of とうきょう as you lose your pursuers.

meaning_mnemonic: You're stuck in <radical>prison</radical> with nothing but a <radical>spoon</radical>, and the <kanji>smell</kanji> in here is so bad you’re using the prison spoon to waft it outside as best you can.
reading_mnemonic: You can’t believe how awful these <kanji>smell</kanji>s are. You’re new in prison, so you call them all <reading>neo</reading>-smells (にお). They're neo, they're new to you.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits, it's <radical>rain</radical>ing, and you're outside trying to use a <radical>rake</radical>, you're going to be very <kanji>wet</kanji> and <kanji>damp</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You can't stand how <kanji>wet</kanji> and <kanji>damp</kanji> you feel in these clothes so you rip them off and rake in the <reading>nu</reading>de (ぬ)!

meaning_mnemonic: You've made yourself a <radical>tree</radical> <radical>bookshelf</radical> (that is, a bookshelf cut into a tree), so you build a <kanji>fence</kanji> to keep the riffraff out.
reading_mnemonic: On your <kanji>fence</kanji>, you hang up a <reading>sack</reading> (さく) to accept donations.

meaning_mnemonic: Who is this <radical>woman</radical> <radical>mole</radical>?! It's your <kanji>niece</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: Not only are they moles, all of your <kanji>niece</kanji>s were also born in <reading>May</reading> (めい)!

examples.en: The former prime minister had the same idea.
examples.ja: 元総理も同じ考えをもっていました。

examples.en: It turned out just as Prime Minister Mori said it would.
examples.ja: 森総理がおっしゃっていた通りになりましたね。

examples.en: Did you hear the prime minister's answer yesterday?
examples.ja: 昨日の総理の答弁はもう聞きましたか？

meaning_mnemonic:
This is an abbreviation of 総理大臣 (prime minister), so this means <vocabulary>prime minister</vocabulary>.

As you learned with 総理大臣, this word is used only for the <vocabulary>Japanese prime minister</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It'll also help if you remember the longer version of this word, 総理大臣.

examples.en: That samurai is famous for how beautifully he assumes the middle-guard stance.
examples.ja: そのサムライは、とても美しい中段の構えをとることで有名です。

examples.en: A bunt position...and then, what a, ho, ho, a home run!
examples.ja: バントの構え…と見せかけてからの、なんと、ホ、ホ、ホームランです！

examples.en: Wow, what a splendidly built house.
examples.ja: うわー、ずいぶん立派な構えの家ですね。

examples.en: In boxing, you need to keep your sides tight in your stance, but I heard that in Muay Thai, it's the opposite - you shouldn't keep your sides tight!
examples.ja: ボクシングの構えは脇をしめなきゃだけど、ムエタイの構えでは逆に脇をしめちゃダメなんだって！

examples.en: This company is demonstrating a stance of litigation against websites that infringed on its copyrights.
examples.ja: この会社は著作権侵害をしたウェブサイトに対して訴訟の構えを見せている。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 構える, which can mean to assume a stance? This is the noun version, making it <vocabulary>stance</vocabulary>.

構え is often used to describe specific stances or <vocabulary>posture</vocabulary>s, both in a literal and figurative sense. In this vein, it can also convey the notion of being mentally and physically prepared for action. Additionally, 構え is also used to refer to the <vocabulary>structure</vocabulary> of something, often focusing on visual appearance.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is like 構える, so as long as you know that you know this too.

examples.en: It's nice to have a temporary measure, but I'm afraid it will happen again later.
examples.ja: 一時的な処置をほどこしたはいいけど、また後で同じことが起こらないか心配だ。

examples.en: If you're looking for Viet, he is disposing of the bug with Scott over there.
examples.ja: ビエトなら、今はあそこでスコットとバグの処置をしてるよ。

examples.en: Is there anyone who could give him first aid?
examples.ja: 誰か彼に応急処置ができる人はいませんか。

meaning_mnemonic:
We're going to <kanji>deal with</kanji> it by <kanji>put</kanji>ting this up your butt and giving you the <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary> you need. Kancho!

処置 is commonly used when treating injuries or illnesses. It can also refer to deciding how to handle a situation or the act of handling it, but in these cases, people usually use 処理 instead.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I just went to the "Food Expo," also known simply as "Shoku-haku!"
examples.ja: 食の博覧会、略して「食博」に行ってきました！

examples.en: You can enter this exhibition free of charge.
examples.ja: この博覧会は無料で入場できます。

examples.en: One of the expos representing Japan is the "Osaka Expo."
examples.ja: 日本を代表する博覧会の一つに、「大阪万博」があります。

examples.en: I just realized that 'banpaku' (world expo) is short for 'bankoku hakurankai'! Everyone calls it 'banpaku,' so I thought that was its official name.
examples.ja: 「万博」って万国博覧会の略だったんですね！みんな「万博」っていうから、それが正式名称なのかと思ってました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>exhibition</kanji> that you <kanji>look at</kanji> and all the people come <kanji>meet</kanji> together. Well, that just sounds like the description of an <vocabulary>exposition</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Don't give up. We still have a faint hope.
examples.ja: あきらめないで。まだ微かな望みが残っているよ。

examples.en: A faint sound could be heard echoing through the silent snowy mountains.
examples.ja: シンと静まり返った雪山に、微かな音が響くのが聞こえました。

examples.en: I heard that Koichi studied Japanese by the dim light of a candle, which worsened his eyesight, so that's why he's wearing glasses.
examples.ja: コウイチはロウソクの微かな明かりで日本語を勉強してたせいで目が悪くなってメガネを掛けているらしいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>delicate</kanji>, and so does this word. Something that's <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary> is probably also <vocabulary>faint</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>indistinct</vocabulary>. So use 微か to describe things like faint sounds, delicate breezes, and indistinct memories.
reading_mnemonic: You should speak in a <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>faint</vocabulary> voice when you <reading>cuss</reading> (かす). So delicate that the cuss words are <vocabulary>indistinct</vocabulary> to other people, even. It's the only acceptable way to cuss.

examples.en: There are many immigrants from Asia in towns along the West coast.
examples.ja: 西海岸ぞいの町にはアジアからの移住者が多い。

examples.en: Let's interview emigrants.
examples.ja: 移住者にインタビューしてみましょう。

examples.en: I received advice on life and work at the immigrant support center.
examples.ja: 移住者支援センターで、生活や仕事の相談に乗ってもらいました。

examples.en: It's not easy to be an international immigrant.
examples.ja: 国外移住者になるのは容易なことではない。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>shift</kanji> the place you <kanji>dwell</kanji>, you’re <kanji>someone</kanji> that we call an <vocabulary>emigrant</vocabulary>, an <vocabulary>immigrant</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>migrant</vocabulary>. Welcome, friend!

You can use this word both for people who migrate between countries and those who migrate within the same country.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I go outside, my allergies stuff up my nose, but when I'm at home, I feel stuffy.
examples.ja: 外に出るとアレルギーで鼻が詰まるけど、家にいると息が詰まるんだよね。

examples.en: Today is packed with things to do, so I'm really busy.
examples.ja: 今日はやることが詰まっていて、とても忙しい。

examples.en: Even though you didn't use toilet paper, the toilet still got clogged. Just how big was the turd you took?!
examples.ja: トイレットペーパーを使ってないのにトイレが詰まるって、どれだけでかいウンコしたんだよ？！

examples.en: I got a fish bone stuck in my throat.
examples.ja: 魚の骨が喉に詰まっちゃった。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stuffed</kanji>. The vocab word is <vocabulary>to be stuffed</vocabulary>, as in something is stuffed and you're not doing the stuffing. You know this because when it comes to まる the cat, he stuffs himself into boxes on his own, so you don't have to stuff him into boxes for him. It just happens, and you can watch and be entertained (obviously you need to go watch some Maru videos if you haven't on YouTube, just saying).
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji!

examples.en: It's hard to describe her charm in just one word.
examples.ja: 彼女の魅力を一言で表すのは難しい。

examples.en: The appeal of this restaurant lies in its affordability and generous portions. The taste is also quite good.
examples.ja: このレストランは安さと量が魅力です。味もなかなかですよ。

examples.en: The appeal of city life is definitely its convenience and exciting lifestyle.
examples.ja: 都会の魅力といえば、やはり便利さと刺激的な生活ですね。

examples.en: I became obsessed with the charm of golf.
examples.ja: 私はゴルフの魅力に取り憑かれてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>alluring</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is the power of <vocabulary>allure</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Why did it take you so long to line up the bowling pins?
examples.ja: ボーリングのピンを並べるのにどうしてそんなに時間がかかったんですか。

examples.en: Many luxury wine bottles are lined up at Mr. Hoshino's house.
examples.ja: 星野さんの家にはたくさんの高級ワインボトルが並べられている。

examples.en: We brainstormed ideas, wrote them on post-its, and laid them out on a whiteboard.
examples.ja: ブレインストーミングで出たアイディアを、ポストイットに書いてホワイトボードに並べました。

examples.en: Please set the plates on the table.
examples.ja: お皿をテーブルに並べてください。

meaning_mnemonic: 並ぶ is when something is lining up. 並べる is when you're lining something up. In other words, 並べる is transitive. It means <vocabulary>to line something up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put something in order</vocabulary>. You know this because when it comes to <reading>bear</reading>s (べる), you have to line them up yourself, because they won't be doing it for you, that's for sure.
reading_mnemonic: The reading of the kanji is same as for 並ぶ, so if you know that you can figure out the reading for this one as well.

examples.en: Greenery is scarce in this town.
examples.ja: この町は緑が乏しい。

examples.en: I don't know if I can handle this job with my lack of experience in company management.…
examples.ja: 会社経営の経験に乏しい私に務まるかどうか...。

examples.en: Efficiency is key for survival in resource-limited companies.
examples.ja: リソースが乏しい企業では、効率化が生き残りのカギです。

examples.en: Not only are my Japanese abilities lacking, but my personal abilities are too.
examples.ja: 日本語能力だけじゃなく、対人能力も乏しいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>scarce</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>scarce</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are <vocabulary>scarce</vocabulary>, you have <reading>to bo</reading>at (とぼ) all the way across the lake to find any resources or food, as your side of the lake is picked dry.

examples.en: How can I know if I’m deficient in Vitamin D?
examples.ja: ビタミンDが欠乏しているかどうかはどうすれば分かりますか。

examples.en: Because I don't like veggies or fruits, I became vitamin deficient.
examples.ja: 野さいもフルーツも嫌いなので、ビタミン欠乏症になってしまった。

examples.en: She has a congenital lack of melanin, commonly known as "albinism."
examples.ja: 彼女は先天的にメラニンが欠乏している、いわゆる「アルビノ」なんだよ。

examples.en: When I went to the doctor, I was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia.
examples.ja: お医者さんに行ったら、鉄欠乏性貧血って診断されました。

meaning_mnemonic: We are <kanji>lack</kanji>ing and things are <kanji>scarce</kanji>. We have a <vocabulary>lack</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>scarcity</vocabulary> of resources.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I forgot to chill the juice, so I'll add ice.
examples.ja: ジュースを冷やすのを忘れたので、氷を入れますね。

examples.en: The beer is chilled, so why don't you have some of that?
examples.ja: ビールを冷やしてあるからそれを飲んだら？

examples.en: Cool your head and think well about what you have done.
examples.ja: 自分が何をしたのか頭を冷やしてよく考えなさい。

examples.en: My finger got caught in the door and I'm chilling it with ice now.
examples.ja: 指をドアで挟んじゃって、今氷で冷やしてるの。

meaning_mnemonic: 冷たい is "cold." This is the verb version, so you're making something cold. This word is <vocabulary>to chill something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cool something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To chill something</vocabulary>, you need to apply cold, not <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ).

examples.en: Thoughts on marriage vary from person to person.
examples.ja: 結婚についての考え方は、人によってさまざまです。

examples.en: Not everybody wants to have a kid right after they get married, right?
examples.ja: 結婚したからって、みんながすぐに子供を作りたい訳じゃないでしょう。

examples.en: My agency tells me that I should keep my marriage hidden.
examples.ja: 事務所から、結婚のことは隠すように言われてるんです。

examples.en: "Shark, how did you know that I got married to Fugu?" "You know. I just heard it through the grapevine."
examples.ja: 「シャーク、私がフグと結婚したってどうして分かったの？」 「ただ人づてに聞いただけさ。」

meaning_mnemonic: Let's <kanji>bind</kanji> this <kanji>marriage</kanji> up with a <vocabulary>marriage</vocabulary>. No better way to make a marriage happen than a marriage, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm thinking of proposing soon.
examples.ja: 近いうちに求婚しようと思うんだ。

examples.en: I'm a Kanji nerd who spends my time studying Kanji on WaniKani, but I'm also receiving daily marriage proposals from a junior at work.
examples.ja: 私はワニカニで漢字の勉強ばかりしている漢字オタクですが、実は会社の後輩から毎日求婚されています。

examples.en: In 19th-century Poland, women without a dowry were sometimes excluded from marriage proposals, no matter how beautiful and educated they were.
examples.ja: 19世紀のポーランドでは、持参金のない女性にはどんなに美しく教養があっても求婚対象から外されることがありました。

examples.en: Hotaru sets impossible tasks for any man who wants to marry her.
examples.ja: ホタルは、どの求婚者にも、結婚の条件として無理難題を突き付けた。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>request</kanji> <kanji>marriage</kanji> with someone else, you are doing a <vocabulary>marriage proposal</vocabulary>. Will you marry me, Brad Pitt?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When are you going on your honeymoon?
examples.ja: 新婚旅行はいつ行くんですか？

examples.en: The schedule of our honeymoon hasn't been decided yet.
examples.ja: 新婚旅行の日程はまだ決まっていません。

examples.en: We went to Hawaii for our honeymoon.
examples.ja: 新婚旅行でハワイに行ってきたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 旅行 is a <kanji>trip</kanji>. The other part is <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>marriage</kanji>. What's the trip you go on after a new marriage? The <vocabulary>honeymoon</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The percentage of unmarried people in Japan is increasing year by year.
examples.ja: 日本では未婚の割合が年々増加しています。

examples.en: A survey was conducted targeting unmarried men and women.
examples.ja: 未婚の男女を対象にした調査が行われました。

examples.en: Since many of my friends are unmarried, we often hold parties for singles.
examples.ja: 未婚の友達が多いので、よく独身者同士でパーティーを開きます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Not yet</kanji> <kanji>marriage</kanji>? You haven't been married. You're <vocabulary>unmarried</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have decided to postpone my return to the country by one week.
examples.ja: 帰国の予定を一週間延ばすことにしました。

examples.en: Currently, there are no plans to extend this railway route.
examples.ja: 今のところ、路線を延ばす計画はありません。

examples.en: Is it possible to extend the repayment term?
examples.ja: 返済期間を延ばすことはできますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>prolong</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to prolong something</vocabulary>.

延ばす conveys the idea of expanding upon something that already exists to make it longer, often in terms of time or physical distance. For example, it can refer to delaying a schedule or extending a railway.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Do you mind if I go <vocabulary>to prolong</vocabulary> things? The answer? "<reading>No</reading> (の), I don't mind."

examples.en: I wonder how many times we've prolonged our time since we came to the karaoke bar?
examples.ja: もうカラオケ店に入ってから何回延長しているんだろうね？

examples.en: Can you write another story as an extension of this one?
examples.ja: この話の延長でもう一つ新しい話が書けないかな？

examples.en: I can't stand how extensions cords get tangled up.
examples.ja: 延長コードがごちゃごちゃになっているのが許せないの。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Prolong</kanji> it for a <kanji>long</kanji> while. We need more time. We need a <vocabulary>prolonging</vocabulary> or <vocabulary> extension</vocabulary> of some kind.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Due to bad weather, the event has been postponed to next week.
examples.ja: 悪天候のため、イベントを来週に延期することになりました。

examples.en: I even postponed my holiday plans to respond to it, but I was told there was no need and that made me really mad.
examples.ja: 休暇の予定を延期してまで対応したのに、必要なかったと言われ腹が立った。

examples.en: I'm discussing with my family whether to postpone the wedding.
examples.ja: 結婚式を延期するかどうか、家族と相談しています。

examples.en: Since the flood caused widespread damage, the high schools in the area postponed their final exams for another month.
examples.ja: その洪水は広範囲に及ぶ被害を引き起こしたため、被害地域の高校は期末試験を一ヶ月延期した。

meaning_mnemonic: Can we <kanji>prolong</kanji> this <kanji>period of time</kanji> to a later date? I want <vocabulary>to postpone</vocabulary>, if possible.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Her voice is very pleasing to the ear, like the babbling of a brook.
examples.ja: 彼女の声は小川のせせらぎのように耳にとても快い。

examples.en: It was very pleasant to walk along the mountain path while feeling the pleasant spring breeze.
examples.ja: 快い春風を感じながら山道を歩くのが、とても気持ちよかったです。

examples.en: The boss doesn't seem to think well of his attitude.
examples.ja: 上司は彼の態度を快く思っていないようです。

examples.en: I felt relieved to have someone willingly take on the task.
examples.ja: 快く引き受けてくれる人がいて、安心しました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pleasant</kanji>? It is also <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word's reading is pretty weird. We're going to think back to a couple different words to put this one together. The word for heart (心), is こころ. The word for good is よい (or いい, but for this word's sake, よい). A "good heart (feeling)" is one where your heart feels nice and warm and fuzzy (figuratively, not literally. If it's literal, go to the hospital please). That is a <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary> feeling. A こころよい feeling.

examples.en: It's actually pleasurable for me to pull out arm hair with tweezers.
examples.ja: 毛抜きで腕の毛を抜くことが快感なんだよね。

examples.en: Can you relate to the pleasure of getting a pencil sharpened just right?
examples.ja: めっちゃ綺麗に鉛筆を削れたときの快感、分かる？

examples.en: The first time I shoplifted, I ended up feeling pleasure in the thrill.
examples.ja: 初めて万引きをした時に、そのスリルに快感を覚えてしまったんです。

examples.en: I don’t want you to be a person who derives pleasure from humiliating people.
examples.ja: 人に恥をかかせることで快感を味わうような人にはなってもらいたくないわ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you have the <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>pleasant</kanji>ness, you are experiencing <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary>.

While 快感 can describe the thrill of achieving something satisfying, it's often associated with <vocabulary>pleasurable feeling</vocabulary>s from taboo or unusual experiences. For example, it might refer to the pleasure of teasing someone, indulging in a bad habit like picking earwax, or feeling sensual delight.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: If you take the express train, you'll reach your destination in thirty minutes.
examples.ja: 快速電車に乗れば、目的地まで30分で着きます。

examples.en: The express train does not stop at this station, so please be careful.
examples.ja: 快速電車は、この駅には止まりませんのでご注意ください。

examples.en: The express train is faster, but I wanted to have a seat, so I took a local train home.
examples.ja: 快速の方が速いけど、座りたかったから各駅に乗って帰った。

examples.en: Yikes! They said the next express bus isn't for another hour.
examples.ja: げげげ！次の快速バス、一時間後だって。

meaning_mnemonic: It's <kanji>pleasant</kanji> but also <kanji>fast</kanji>. When getting on a train, it's nice to find a train that's both of these things. What makes it pleasant? That would be the <vocabulary>high speed</vocabulary>. What makes it fast? Also the <vocabulary>high speed</vocabulary>. Really, if you're on a train you'd rather get to your destination sooner than later, so a high speed 快速 train is the way to go.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The fabric of this clothing feels rough, and I find it uncomfortable.
examples.ja: この服は生地がザラザラしていて不快に感じます。

examples.en: It feels really unpleasant when you touch me.
examples.ja: あなたに触られるととっても不快なんです。

examples.en: How can you not realize that comments like that might make others uncomfortable?
examples.ja: そういうコメントが他人を不快にさせる可能性があるってこと、なんで分からないの？

examples.en: I don't want to laugh at my boss's unpleasant jokes and I hate myself when I do.
examples.ja: 上司の不快なジョークに笑いたくもないのに笑っている自分が嫌いです。

meaning_mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>pleasant</kanji> are <vocabulary>unpleasant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>uncomfortable</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How nostalgic! We used to do that a lot when we were kids, didn't we?
examples.ja: 懐かしい！小さいころ、よくやったよね。

examples.en: This taste feels kind of nostalgic.
examples.ja: この味、なんだか懐かしい感じがする。

examples.en: A nostalgic song started playing from the speaker.
examples.ja: 懐かしい曲がスピーカーから流れてきました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>nostalgia</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>nostalgic</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Do you remember doing that? Oh man, those were the days. How 懐かしい.

examples.en: If you press this red button, the light will turn on.
examples.ja: この赤いボタンを押すと、電気がつきます。

examples.en: It's hard to walk on a mountain trail while pushing a stroller.
examples.ja: ベビーカーを押して山道を歩くのは大変です。

examples.en: Please stamp your seal here.
examples.ja: ここにハンコを押してください。

examples.en: I'm sorry, I forgot to punch my timecard this morning. What should I do?
examples.ja: すみません。今朝タイムカードを押し忘れちゃったんですが、どうすればいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>push</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to push</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually!

examples.en: When recording a video, be careful to avoid camera shake.
examples.ja: 動画を撮るとき、手ブレしないように注意してください。

examples.en: I took a lot of photos at my kid's kindergarten graduation ceremony.
examples.ja: 子供の幼稚園の卒園式で記念写真をたくさん撮りました。

examples.en: Michael should know details about how to take selfies well.
examples.ja: マイケルは自撮りを上手に撮る方法について詳しく知っているはずです。

examples.en: He put his baseball cap on backwards to take the picture.
examples.ja: 写真を撮るために、彼は野球帽を後ろ向きに被り直した。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>photograph</kanji>. When you make that into a verb, it becomes <vocabulary>to take a picture</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to take a video</vocabulary>. Basically, it's for any form of shooting you do with a camera!
reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To take a picture</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to take a video</vocabulary>… You "take" all these things. And how do you say "to take" in Japanese? It's <reading>取る</reading> (とる), which happens to share a reading with this word. Different kanji but related meanings, and exactly the same reading!

examples.en: The actress has been living in a hotel for half a year while filming a movie.
examples.ja: その女優は映画の撮影で半年もホテルぐらしをしている。

examples.en: Flash photography is prohibited here.
examples.ja: ここでは、フラッシュを使っての撮影は禁止されています。

examples.en: The footage shot from the sky using a drone was very beautiful.
examples.ja: ドローンを使って空から撮影した映像がとても美しかったです。

examples.en: I'm sorry to have kept you waiting. Let's start shooting now.
examples.ja: お待たせして申し訳ございません。それでは、撮影を始めましょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>photograph</kanji> a <kanji>shadow</kanji>, you're obviously doing some kind of <vocabulary>photography</vocabulary>. (In the old days photography meant using light to burn shadows onto special paper, but now it's all fancy and digital.) This isn't just still photography though; it also means <vocabulary>filming</vocabulary> (as in a video or movie). Basically, if it has to do with taking photos or video, 撮影 is your dude.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Be careful at that station. There are a lot of secret filming cases there.
examples.ja: あの駅、盗撮が多いから気をつけたほうがいいよ。

examples.en: Whenever I come across voyeuristic videos on social media, I make sure to report them.
examples.ja: SNSで盗撮動画を見かけたら、いつも通報するようにしています。

examples.en: I tried to secretly film my friend sleeping, but they ended up secretly filming me doing that instead!
examples.ja: 友達が寝てるところを盗撮しようとしたら、逆にそれを盗撮されてた！

examples.en: Photos were taken of me in secret while I was napping on the train.
examples.ja: 電車内で居眠りしているところを盗撮されたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Steal</kanji>ing <kanji>photograph</kanji>s of you. Wait, you didn't know you were being photographed or filmed? That's <vocabulary>secret photography</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>secret filming</vocabulary>. Creeeeeepy.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Diagnosing your symptoms on your own is risky.
examples.ja: 自分で症状を診断するのは危険だよ。

examples.en: I had my dog's illness diagnosed at the animal hospital.
examples.ja: 動物病院で犬の病気を診断してもらいました。

examples.en: Although I am Tokyo-born and raised, a quiz assessing whether participants are from Kanto or Kansai incorrectly pegged me as someone from Kansai.
examples.ja: 関東人か関西人かを問うクイズで、東京生まれの東京育ちなのになぜか関西人と診断されました。

examples.en: Right before the doctor diagnosed me with cancer, a nurse glanced over her shoulder at me.
examples.ja: その医者が私に癌だと診断するほんの少し前に、ある看護婦さんが私の事をちらっと振り返って見たんです。

meaning_mnemonic: 診断 is a <kanji>diagnosis</kanji>. Make this into a verb, and you have <vocabulary>to diagnose</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'd like to learn how to send signals with a flag.
examples.ja: 旗で合図を送る方法を学んでみたいです。

examples.en: This flag is put up here as a symbol of the tribe.
examples.ja: この旗は部族のシンボルとしてここにかかげられています。

examples.en: I participated in a flag-making event and came up with an original design.
examples.ja: 旗を作るイベントに参加して、オリジナルデザインを考えました。

examples.en: I impulsively bought the toothpicks with cute flags on them.
examples.ja: 私は可愛い旗がついている爪楊枝を衝動買いしてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The one with the <vocabulary>flag</vocabulary> is the Mad <reading>Hatter</reading> (はた). Just imagine looking through a group of people. You have to find the Mad Hatter, and he has to find you. That's why he offered to wear a flag on his hat.

examples.en: The Japanese national flag has the sun drawn on a white cloth.
examples.ja: 日本の国旗には白地に日の丸がかかれています。

examples.en: My friends and I had a lot of fun with a world flag quiz!
examples.ja: 世界の国旗クイズで友達と盛り上がりました！

examples.en: At the Olympics, athletes enter carrying their national flags.
examples.ja: オリンピックでは選手たちが国旗を背負って入場します。

examples.en: No way! You bought this huge national flag? Where the heck are you thinking of putting it up?
examples.ja: やっべーな。お前この巨大国旗を買ったのかよ？いったいどこに掲げるつもりなの？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>country</kanji>'s <kanji>flag</kanji> is the flag they use for their nation. It's the <vocabulary>national flag</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to こっ, though, so look out for that.

examples.en: Wouldn't it be better to have a light blue color in the background?
examples.ja: 背景は水色の方がいいんじゃない？

examples.en: This background would definitely look good on Instagram!
examples.ja: この背景はきっとインスタ映えするね！

examples.en: In counseling, it is important to understand the background of the issues being discussed.
examples.ja: カウンセリングでは、相談内容の背景を知ることが重要です。

examples.en: Could you take my picture with the Tofugu headquarters in the background?
examples.ja: トーフグの本社を背景にして写真を撮ってもらえませんか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>back</kanji> <kanji>scene</kanji> is the scene going on in the back. You don't really notice it, because it's the <vocabulary>background</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is hard to rehabilitate juvenile delinquents.
examples.ja: 不良少年を更生させるのは大変です。

examples.en: It's rare for perpetrators of domestic violence to naturally reform themselves.
examples.ja: ＤＶの加害者が自然に更生することは、ほとんどありません。

examples.en: She believes that there is hope of rehabilitation for her son.
examples.ja: 彼女は自分の息子は更生の見込みがあると信じている。

examples.en: The company filed for reorganization under the Company Resuscitation Law.
examples.ja: その会社は、会社更生法を申請しました。

examples.en: If you want to stop the crime that a criminal plans to commit someday, you only have two options: rehabilitate the criminal, or keep them in prison until they're rehabilitated, right?
examples.ja: ある犯罪者がいつかする予定の犯罪を止めるには、この犯罪者を更生させるか、その犯罪者が更生するまで出所させないかの二つのオプションしかないじゃないですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Experiencing a <kanji>renew</kanji>al of <kanji>life</kanji> means going through a process of <vocabulary>rehabilitation</vocabulary>.

 更生 generally refers to rehabilitation from various issues such as addiction, crime,  delinquency, or personal struggles. Ideally, this leads to <vocabulary>reforming oneself</vocabulary> and reintegrating into society.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: After switching to a new pillow, I've been sleeping much better.
examples.ja: 新しい枕に変えたら、よく眠れるようになりました。

examples.en: I have a bit of a preference when it comes to pillows.
examples.ja: 私は枕にはちょっとしたこだわりがあるんです。

examples.en: I ended up buying an expensive pillow for my husband.
examples.ja: 結局夫のために高い枕を買うはめになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, huzzah!

examples.en: Watermelons and pumpkins float in water.
examples.ja: スイカもカボチャも水に浮く。

examples.en: After drinking, I felt light and floaty, as if I were floating in the air.
examples.ja: お酒を飲んだら、宙に浮いているようなフワフワした感じになった。

examples.en: If we, two middle-aged guys, were playing house in a place like this, we'd totally stand out!
examples.ja: こんなとこでおっさん二人がおままごとをしてたら、完全に浮くだろ！

examples.en: Would you like to have some tea? I'll treat you. I got some money to spare because the sunglasses I wanted were on sale.
examples.ja: 良かったら、お茶でもしない？おごるよ。ほしかったサングラスがセール中だったもんで、お金が浮いたんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>float</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to float</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji. う!

examples.en: Why don't we talk about the ukiyo-e?
examples.ja: その浮世絵についてお話をしませんか？

examples.en: This is a famous ukiyo-e, right?
examples.ja: これって有名な浮世絵だよね？

examples.en: Let's get in touch with the Ukiyo-e Society of Japan.
examples.ja: 日本浮世絵協会に連絡してみましょう。

examples.en: Why don't we have Aya draw a woodblock print style Tofugu illustration?
examples.ja: アヤに浮世絵スタイルのトーフグの絵を描いてもらおうよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>float</kanji>ing <kanji>world</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is what you call an <vocabulary>ukiyo-e woodblock print</vocabulary> in Japan. The "floating world" refers to an evanescent world that is impermanent (floating), just as beauty and entertainment are. Back in the day, this type of art was made into woodblock prints and paintings. Unfortunately, we don't have a name for these in English because they're so unique and special, but they come up more than you'd think, so get used to ukiyo-e!
reading_mnemonic: The readings don't really line up perfectly, but they're close (although mixed in terms of what has what reading). Take a look at the word and break everything down. 浮 takes the kun'yomi うき (from 浮く), 世 also takes the kun'yomi よ, and then 絵 takes the on'yomi え. Put that all together and you have うきよえ! Or if you already know the word ukiyo-e, that works too!

examples.en: He admitted to cheating and apologized.
examples.ja: 彼は浮気を認めて、謝罪しました。

examples.en: My friend called me crying, saying "I was cheated on!"
examples.ja: 友達が「浮気された！」って泣きながら電話してきたんだよね…。

examples.en: I was emotionally shocked by my husband's infidelity.
examples.ja: 夫の浮気に、精神的なショックを受けました。

examples.en: "So he had an affair and then blamed it on you for not having a cellphone?" "That about sums it up."
examples.ja: 「彼は浮気をして、それを携帯電話を持っていないあなたのせいにしたってこと？」「要約するとそんなところね。」

meaning_mnemonic: You are <kanji>float</kanji>ing above everything, at least that's how your <kanji>spirit</kanji> feels. You're having an <vocabulary>affair</vocabulary>, and feel like nothing will catch you but... wait, what's that? Is that your wife? Oh no... not floating anymore, you're not.
reading_mnemonic: This kanji uses the kun'yomi read for the first kanji, and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too.

examples.en: I'm thirsty. Can you go buy me some juice?
examples.ja: 喉が渇くからジュース買ってきて！

examples.en: I only exercised for three minutes, but I'm already thirsty.
examples.ja: まだ三分しか運動してないのに喉が渇いてきました。

examples.en: Well, I was really thirsty so I drank too much beer. I’m drunk now~
examples.ja: ええっと、喉がカラカラに渇いてたから、ビールを飲み過ぎちゃったんだよね。俺は今、ベロベロだ〜。

examples.en: She seemed to have been thirsting for love the whole time.
examples.ja: 彼女はずっと愛に渇いているように見えました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you have a <kanji>thirst</kanji>, you tend <vocabulary>to become thirsty</vocabulary>.

Note that this does not mean “to be thirsty” by itself, but only in combination with 喉, as in 喉が渇く.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go grab a cup of water so you don't become dehydrated, okay?

examples.en: The cause of the water leak was an old pipe.
examples.ja: 漏水の原因は古くなったパイプでした。

examples.en: I called the management company about a possible water leak, and they came right away!
examples.ja: 漏水してるかもって管理会社に電話したら、すぐに来てくれたよ！

examples.en: Water leakage can cause issues with electrical systems.
examples.ja: 漏水が原因で電気系統にトラブルが起きることもあります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>leak</kanji> of <kanji>water</kanji> is a <vocabulary>water leakage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Gas is leaking from the totally destroyed building and it's dangerous, so don't get near.
examples.ja: ﻿全壊したビルからガスが漏出して危険だから近寄らないように。

examples.en: The leakage of chemicals caused environmental issues.
examples.ja: 化学物質の漏出が環境問題を引き起こしました。

examples.en: What kind of measures does your company take to prevent accidental leakage of crude oil into the sea?
examples.ja: 原油の海への漏出事故を防ぐために、どんな手段を講じていますか。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something is <kanji>leak</kanji>ing and whatever is leaking is <kanji>exit</kanji>ing what it was in before. This is when a <vocabulary>leak</vocabulary> occurs.

漏出 is a formal word that means <vocabulary>leakage</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>spillage</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>seepage</vocabulary>. It's often used for physical leaks of substances like liquids, gases, or other materials.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I installed soundproofing materials on the wall to prevent noise leakage.
examples.ja: 音が漏れるので、カベに防音材を取り付けました。

examples.en: Hey, doesn’t it smell like leaking gas?
examples.ja: ねえ、なんかガスが漏れてる臭いがしない？

examples.en: Oh no! I'm about to pee myself! I might poop too…
examples.ja: やばい！おしっこ漏れる！ウンチも漏れそう…。

examples.en: The FBI is currently investigating where the classified national information leaked from.
examples.ja: 今FBIが国家機密情報がどこから漏れたのか捜査しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>leak</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to leak</vocabulary>.

漏れる can be used for both physical and abstract leakage, like water or gas leaking, sound or light seeping out, or information or emotions being revealed unintentionally.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Causing you <vocabulary>to leak</vocabulary> all over the floor (we're talking blood, here) is your friend <reading>Moe</reading> (も). If you know someone named Moe, imagine them doing this. If you don't, think of a famous Moe.

examples.en: Oh, thank you. I'm blushing!
examples.ja: えっ、有り難う。照れるなぁ。

examples.en: His bashful expression was so cute.
examples.ja: 照れる彼の表情がとても可愛かったんです。

examples.en: My friend said, "You're looking cool," and I couldn't help but blush.
examples.ja: 友達に「お前、かっこいいな」って言われて、思わず照れちゃった。

examples.en: At the matchmaking arrangement this weekend, the other party was so shy that the conversation just didn't flow.
examples.ja: 週末のお見合いでは、相手が照れてばっかりいて全然会話がはずまなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your feel as if your cheeks are <kanji>illuminate</kanji>d when you start <vocabulary>to feel shy</vocabulary>. Probably illuminated in red, which is why this also means <vocabulary>to blush</vocabulary>. 

照れる means <vocabulary>to be bashful</vocabulary>, often in situations where the embarrassment stems from modesty rather than serious discomfort. It's used to describe feeling self-conscious in an endearing way, such as blushing due to praise, attention, or being teased in a lighthearted manner.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you feel the most embarrassed about is your <reading>手</reading> (て). It's all blue and scary looking.

examples.en: The lighting in this room is too bright.
examples.ja: この部屋の照明は明るすぎます。

examples.en: Setting up lighting for the outdoor event took a lot of time.
examples.ja: 野外イベントの照明設置に時間がかかりました。

examples.en: I went to an illumination design exhibition.
examples.ja: 照明デザインの展示会に行きました。

examples.en: A couple of flies are buzzing around the lighting equipment.
examples.ja: 照明器具の周りを蠅が2-3匹ブンブン飛び交っている。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Illuminate</kanji> and make things <kanji>bright</kanji>, my <vocabulary>illumination</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm really looking forward to the publication of this novel!
examples.ja: この小説の出版、すごく楽しみにしてるね！

examples.en: Thanks to your support, the book I released last year became a huge million-seller success.
examples.ja: 去年出版した本は、おかげさまでミリオンセラーの大ヒットとなりました。

examples.en: I went to Nagasaki not for pleasure, but on publishing business.
examples.ja: 長崎には、遊びではなく出版の仕事で行ったんです。

examples.en: It took me two years to publish the book.
examples.ja: その本を出版するのに二年もかかりました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>exit</kanji> that <kanji>edition</kanji> out of your hands and into the world, you've gotten something published! That is <vocabulary>publishing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Does the publishing company have the copyright?
examples.ja: 版権は出版社にあるの？

examples.en: The copyright for this design will expire in 2025.
examples.ja: このデザインの版権は2025年に切れます。

examples.en: Who holds the copyright for this work?
examples.ja: この作品の版権は誰が持っていますか？

examples.en: This letter states the possible contract renewal date for the copyright.
examples.ja: この手紙には、版権に関する契約更新予定日が記載されています。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>edition</kanji> <kanji>rights</kanji> over this. This edition is yours, and if anyone copies this edition, they get in trouble. You have <vocabulary>copyright</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Wow, you have the first printing? So cool!
examples.ja: 初版を持ってるなんて、すごいね！

examples.en: I didn't know the first edition had a premium price.
examples.ja: 初版にプレミアがついてるなんて知らなかったよ。

examples.en: I have the first edition, but maybe I'll buy the reprint too.
examples.ja: 初版ならもう持ってるけど、重版も買おうかな。

examples.en: The first edition of his novel sold out in six months.
examples.ja: 彼の小説の初版は半年で売り切れた。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>first edition</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I saw the cat stealing a fish.
examples.ja: 猫が魚を盗むところを見てしまった。

examples.en: That means you're stealing other people's time!
examples.ja: それって他人の時間を盗んでるってことなんだよ！

examples.en: Is it wrong to steal someone else's idea?
examples.ja: 誰かのアイデアを盗むことは、悪いことなんでしょうか？

examples.en: He's the kind of guy who never does something halfway, so he must have a magnificent plan to steal the 3106 carat diamond.
examples.ja: あいつは絶対に中途半端なことはしない奴だから、3106カラットのダイヤモンドを盗むための壮大な計画を立てているに違いない。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>steal</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to steal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: What are you going <vocabulary>to steal</vocabulary>? How about a <reading>noose</reading> (ぬす)? Wait, why are you stealing a noose? That sounds like trouble to me...

examples.en: I heard that store was robbed, but thankfully no one was injured.
examples.ja: あの店、強盗が入ったらしいよ！でも、幸い誰もケガはなかったって。

examples.en: A robber turned that corner just now!
examples.ja: たった今、強盗がそこの角を曲がって行きましたよ！

examples.en: What, the person who got arrested for the crime of burglary yesterday was your mother?!
examples.ja: え、昨日強盗の罪で逮捕された人って、あなたのお母さんだったの？！

examples.en: Do you want to rob a bank? It's now or never.
examples.ja: 銀行強盗をやってみないか？今を逃がすと一生ないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You are <kanji>strong</kanji> so you break into someone's home, hold them up, then <kanji>steal</kanji> from them. Ha ha! Take that, next door neighbor! This is a <vocabulary>burglary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>robbery</vocabulary>, depending on how crazy you get after you use that strength to break down that door.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But 強  has two on'yomi readings, and you haven't really seen this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Think about how when you commit a <vocabulary>robbery</vocabulary>, you <reading>go</reading> (ごう) into someone's house, then you go to jail as well, if you're caught.

examples.en: Doesn't that author's new work seem like plagiarism?
examples.ja: あの作家の新作、なんか盗作っぽくない？

examples.en: Plagiarism is a big issue in American universities as well.
examples.ja: 盗作はアメリカの大学でも大きな問題になっています。

examples.en: The novelist who stole somebody else's story and published it as if it were his own appeared in the news.
examples.ja: 盗作した話を自分が書いた小説として本を出版した小説家がニュースに出ていた。

examples.en: If you stole someone else's work, you could be sued for plagiarism.
examples.ja: 他人の作品をパクったら、盗作で訴えられるかもしれないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Steal</kanji> what other people <kanji>make</kanji>? Wow. Way to go. That is <vocabulary>plagiarism</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: They make money by reselling stolen items.
examples.ja: アイツらは、盗品の転売をしてかせいでいるんだ。

examples.en: If you find stolen goods at an auction, report it immediately.
examples.ja: オークションで盗品を見つけた場合、すぐに通報してください。

examples.en: It seems like the item my friend bought online was actually a stolen item. What should they do if they unknowingly bought stolen goods?
examples.ja: 友達がネットで買った物が、実は盗品だったみたいだ。盗品だと知らずに買っちゃったら、どうすればいいんだろう？

examples.en: People sell stolen goods here, so it's called "thieves' market."
examples.ja: ここではみんな盗品を売ってるので、「泥棒市場」と呼ばれています。

meaning_mnemonic: These are <kanji>stolen</kanji> (steal) <kanji>goods</kanji>. So, I'll give you a deal, because, you know, they're <vocabulary>stolen goods</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Every morning, I drop my child off at kindergarten at 8 a.m. before heading to work.
examples.ja: 毎朝、子どもを朝8時に幼稚園に送り届けてから仕事に行きます。

examples.en: Kindergartens have many fun events like sports days and field trips.
examples.ja: 幼稚園では、運動会や遠足などの楽しいイベントがたくさんあります。

examples.en: Apparently she didn't want to go to the kindergarten because the portion of the school lunch was too much.
examples.ja: 給食の量が多すぎるので、幼稚園に行きたくなかったみたいなんです。

examples.en: We might have to make another small adjustment to the kindergarten Christmas party schedule.
examples.ja: 幼稚園のクリスマス会のスケジュールをまた微調整しなくちゃいけないかもしれないの。

meaning_mnemonic: If 幼稚 is <kanji>childish</kanji>, then a <kanji>garden</kanji> for childish people would be a place full of lots of children, probably growing in some way. When you're growing little children in a garden, you're putting them into some kind of school. In this case, it's a <vocabulary>kindergarten</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 幼稚 as well.

examples.en: You can't ride the train without a ticket.
examples.ja: 切符がないと電車に乗れないよ。

examples.en: Please insert your ticket into the ticket gate.
examples.ja: 切符を改札機に通してください。

examples.en: I bought a ticket for the streetcar at the station.
examples.ja: 駅でチンチン電車の切符を購入しました。

examples.en: You can buy tickets for that tour on site.
examples.ja: そのツアーの切符は、現地で購入することもできます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cut</kanji> <kanji>token</kanji> is a token you cut out from a sheet of paper into smaller sheets, and each of these pieces is a <vocabulary>ticket</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 切る cut short to きっ, then ふ rendaku'd to ぷ. It's a bit of a troublesome word, so concentrate on this now a bit so you can get it in the reviews.

examples.en: I will do my best for the team.
examples.ja: チームのために精一杯努力します。

examples.en: He gave the presentation with all his effort.
examples.ja: 彼は精一杯のプレゼンをしました。

examples.en: I tried my best until the deadline at 5 p.m. on August 30th.
examples.ja: 八月三十日午後五時の締切まで、精一杯頑張りました。

examples.en: Getting rid of old pictures is the best I can do for now.
examples.ja: 今は古い写真を捨てることが私にできる精一杯です。

meaning_mnemonic: You put <kanji>one cup of liquid</kanji>... no, one full cup of liquid <kanji>spirit</kanji> into what you're doing. None of this half-cup garbage. A full one. That means you're going at it <vocabulary>with all one's might</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you've seen 一杯 before.

examples.en: I believe our child needs mental care right now.
examples.ja: この子には、今は精神的なケアが必要だと思うんです。

examples.en: Tofugu's blog gave me emotional support during my hospital stay.
examples.ja: トーフグのブログが、入院中の私の精神的な支えになっていました。

examples.en: He had quit his job due to mental stress.
examples.ja: 彼は精神的ストレスが原因で仕事を辞めることになりました。

examples.en: When I was mentally troubled, I was wandering aimlessly around the park alone every day.
examples.ja: 精神的に病んでいた時、毎日一人で公園をブラブラしていました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your 精神 is your spirit or your mind. If you add 的 to it, you get <vocabulary>mental</vocabulary>. It can mean <vocabulary>spiritual</vocabulary> too, but it more often shows up in reference to a person's mental or <vocabulary>emotional</vocabulary> state.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My father is suffering from a mental illness and is in hospital.
examples.ja: 父は精神病をわずらって入院しています。

examples.en: Mental illness is closely related to physical health.
examples.ja: 精神病と身体の健康は深く関係しています。

examples.en: My cat started acting weird, and I wondered, "Is this a mental illness?"
examples.ja: 猫が急に変な動きをしていて、「これって精神病かな？」と思っちゃった。

meaning_mnemonic:
精神 is your spirit or mind, the non-physical part of you. When it's <kanji>sick</kanji>, it's a <vocabulary>mental illness</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mental disorder</vocabulary>.

Note that the term 精神病, when used on its own, carries a stigma and is considered a bit disrespectful and outdated.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know 精神 already, though.

examples.en: There are a lot of Korean Americans living in my town.
examples.ja: 私の町には韓国系アメリカ人がたくさん住んでいます。

examples.en: I like romance-type movies, but I'm not good with horror ones.
examples.ja: 私は恋愛系の映画が好きだけど、ホラー系は苦手です。

examples.en: If you were to ask whether Akio is a herbivore-type or a carnivore-type guy, he'd definitely be the carnivore-type.
examples.ja: 草食系か肉食系かと言ったら、アキオは絶対肉食系でしょ。

examples.en: Somehow I'm attracted to nerdy, Akihabara-style men.
examples.ja: 私、アキバ系のオタッキーな男性に何故か魅力を感じるんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Trace something back through its <kanji>lineage</kanji> to determine what <vocabulary>type</vocabulary> of thing it is. 

〜系 is a suffix you can attach casually to a word to classify it as a <vocabulary>genre</vocabulary> or group, like 理系 (science-oriented fields), おしゃれ系 (trendy or stylish people), or 日系 (Japanese descendants).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because this word gets stuck onto other things to describe tribes and groups.

examples.en: Many Japanese Americans live in Los Angeles.
examples.ja: ロサンゼルスには多くの日系アメリカ人が住んでいます。

examples.en: What are the merits of working for a Japanese company in America?
examples.ja: アメリカで日系企業につとめるメリットは何ですか。

examples.en: I only use Japanese airlines.
examples.ja: 私は日系の飛行機しか乗らないようにしています。

examples.en: My wife is a third-generation American of Japanese descent.
examples.ja: 私の妻は日系アメリカ人の三世です。

meaning_mnemonic:
The 日 stands for 日本 here, making it mean "Japanese." So what's a more common way of saying Japanese <kanji>lineage</kanji>? That would be <vocabulary>Japanese descent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Japanese origin</vocabulary>.

日系 can be used for both people and entities, such as 日系アメリカ人 (Japanese-American) or 日系企業 (Japanese-operated company).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Around where in the Milky Way is the solar system located?
examples.ja: 太陽系は銀河系のどの辺りにある？

examples.en: Today in science class, we learned about the birth of the solar system.
examples.ja: 今日は科学のクラスで太陽系の誕生について学びました。

examples.en: At the center of the solar system is, of course, the Sun.
examples.ja: 太陽系の中心にあるのは、もちろん太陽です。

examples.en: How many planets does the solar system have?
examples.ja: 太陽系には惑星はいくつあるんだっけ？

meaning_mnemonic: You know 太陽 means "sun," so hopefully you can guess what a sun <kanji>system</kanji> is. That's right — it's the <vocabulary>solar system</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 太陽.

examples.en: I am thinking about buying a book that summarizes economic theories systematically.
examples.ja: 経済学の理論について、体系的にまとめた本を買いたいと思っています。

examples.en: Prof. Baba and Prof. Morimoto are conducting systematic research on communication theories.
examples.ja: 馬場教授と森本教授はコミュニケーション理論について体系的な研究をしている。

examples.en: Organizing problems systematically leads to early solutions.
examples.ja: 問題を体系的に整理することで、早期の解決につながります。

examples.en: We are offering systematic Japanese learning material.
examples.ja: 私達は、体系的な日本語学習教材を提供しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Give a <kanji>body</kanji> to a <kanji>system</kanji> to make it a real, structured system, you know? Then add 的 to it to make it <vocabulary>systematic</vocabulary>.

体系的 is a formal word for something that follows a clear structure or framework, often used in academic contexts. For example, you might hear it when discussing a systematic approach to solving a problem or organizing information systematically.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We are very grateful for the uninterrupted supply of electricity and water.
examples.ja: 電気や水が絶えることなく供給されているのはとてもありがたいことです。

examples.en: It's sad, but Koichi's life has ended here.
examples.ja: 悲しいけど、コウイチの命はここで絶えてしまったんだ。

examples.en: Since Tofugu members ate a mushroom called "panaeolus papilionaceus," there has been no end to the laughter in the Tofugu office.
examples.ja: トーフグメンバーが笑い茸と呼ばれるキノコを食べてからというもの、トーフグのオフィスでは、笑いが絶えることはない。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>die out</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to die out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come to an end</vocabulary>.

絶える is mostly used for when something that was ongoing comes to an end, like breath stopping, laughter fading away, a supply being cut off, or foot traffic dying down. You know this because when something dies out, nothing is left but thin air (える).
reading_mnemonic: The reading can come from 絶つ, so as long as you know that word you know this one as well.

examples.en: The day after the sports tournament, my whole body was sore, and it was tough.
examples.ja: スポーツ大会の翌日は、体中が痛くて大変でした。

examples.en: What were you doing the day after you returned from your trip?
examples.ja: 旅行から帰ってきた翌日は、何をしていたんですか？

examples.en: The railroad service went back to normal the next day.
examples.ja: 列車は翌日平常運転にもどりました。

examples.en: Due to heavy snowfall, the event was postponed to the following day.
examples.ja: 大雪の影響でイベントは翌日に延期されました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is just that, <vocabulary>the next day</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I joined the company in April, and training started the following month
examples.ja: 4月に入社し、翌月に研修が始まった。

examples.en: He was hospitalized due to cancer and was discharged the following month.
examples.ja: 彼はガンで入院し、翌月に退院しました。

examples.en: The accident occurred in August, and safety measures were reinforced the following month.
examples.ja: 事故が発生したのは8月で、その翌月に安全対策が強化されました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>month</kanji> is <vocabulary>the next month</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I woke up the next morning, I had a hangover with a throbbing headache.
examples.ja: 翌朝目が覚めると、二日よいで頭がガンガンしていた。

examples.en: The next morning, we traveled another eight kilometers north.
examples.ja: 翌朝、更に八キロ北上しました。

examples.en: I was instructed to complete the report by the next morning.
examples.ja: 翌朝までに報告書を完成させるように指示されたんです。

examples.en: I'm afraid that your 9 p.m. foot-pressure massage has been pushed back to 9:30 tomorrow morning.
examples.ja: 申し訳ありませんが、お客様の足つぼマッサージのご予約は、本日の夜9時から翌朝9時30分にご変更されております。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>morning</kanji> is <vocabulary>the next morning</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses a mix of on'yomi and kun'yomi readings, but, lucky for you, those are the readings you learned with the kanji. Use the readings you learned, and you shouldn't have any problem!

examples.en: Mr. Hino started his business the year after he returned to Japan from America.
examples.ja: 日野さんはアメリカから日本に帰国した翌年に起業しました。

examples.en: He started working abroad the year after graduating from university.
examples.ja: 彼は大学を卒業した翌年に海外で働き始めました。

examples.en: I started working for Japan Ukiyo-e Museum just as a part-time worker, but I got promoted to full-time the following year.
examples.ja: 財団法人日本浮世絵博物館でアルバイトとして働き始めたんですが、翌年には正社員に登用されました。

examples.en: He started his business the next year.
examples.ja: 翌年彼は起業しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>The next</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji> is <vocabulary>the next year</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading can be the on'yomi for 年 or the kun'yomi. So, you can do either よくねん or よくとし, or preferably both.

examples.en: You've grown taller in the time we haven't seen each other!
examples.ja: しばらく見ない間に背、のびたね！

examples.en: Please line up in order of height.
examples.ja: 背の順に並んでください。

examples.en: He was reading a book while resting his back against the wall.
examples.ja: 彼はカベに背をもたれかけながら、本を読んでいました。

examples.en: Is your friend the tall woman in the purple dress?
examples.ja: 紫色のドレスを着ている背の高い女性は、あなたのご友人ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Where you're from, everyone measures their <vocabulary>height</vocabulary> in <reading>ce</reading>lery (せ). No inches or centimeters for you, it's celery sticks only. How many celery sticks tall are you?

examples.en: I made a list of Japanese words that I want to memorize.
examples.ja: 覚えたい日本語の単語の一覧を作りました。

examples.en: I've compiled a list of books on African history for easy reference.
examples.ja: アフリカの歴史書をまとめて一覧できるようにしてみました。

examples.en: If you press this key and this key at the same time, a list of keyboard shortcuts will appear.
examples.ja: このキーとこのキーを同時に押したら、キーボードショートカットの一覧が出てくるよ。

examples.en: I'm struggling to find my boss's name on my contact list.
examples.ja: 連絡先の一覧から中々上司の名前が見つからないんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic:
With just <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>look at</kanji> something you're able to take in all the info you need, because that something is <vocabulary>a list</vocabulary>. A nice list that gives you <vocabulary>an overview</vocabulary> at a glance. Perfect for all that <vocabulary>looking over</vocabulary> you have to do. You busy consumer of information, you.

一覧 usually refers to a neat list you can skim over easily to get the info you need, like a guest list or a data table. With する, it becomes a pretty formal verb for looking over something in a quick way, like skimming through a report or casually checking out a place.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please enjoy watching the show!
examples.ja: それではショーを楽しんでご覧ください。

examples.en: As you can see, I am all better now.
examples.ja: ご覧の通り、今はもうすっかり元気になりました。

examples.en: The documentary you just watched was made in America in 1996.
examples.ja: 今ご覧いただいたドキュメンタリーは1996年にアメリカで製作されたものです。

examples.en: Have you seen your daughter's examination results yet?
examples.ja: 娘さんの試験の結果はもうご覧になられましたか。

meaning_mnemonic:
ご覧 is the polite noun form of 見る and means <vocabulary>looking at</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>seeing</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>watching</vocabulary>. It's often paired with 〜になる, as in ご覧になる, which is a respectful way to describe someone else's 見る action.

Some other common phrases you might hear are ご覧ください (please take a look) or ご覧のとおり (as you can see). They're formal but common in polite speech, such as in customer service or business presentations. ご覧 can even be used on its own as a gentle command, like ほら、そこをご覧 ("Hey, look over there").
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Go look at the next lesson, now.

examples.en: The viewing seats are already full.
examples.ja: 観覧席はもう満席になりました。

examples.en: Photography is prohibited during the viewing.
examples.ja: 観覧中は写真撮影が禁止されています。

examples.en: Throw it properly! I didn't come to see you throw a practice ball!
examples.ja: ちゃんと投げろ！遊び球を投げるところを観覧しに来たんじゃないぞ！

examples.en: I watched the TofuguTV filming.
examples.ja: トーフグテレビの撮影現場を観覧しました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>view</kanji> and <kanji>look at</kanji> something, you are <vocabulary>viewing</vocabulary> that thing, or <vocabulary>watching</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I grow up, I want to work to help poor people.
examples.ja: 大人になったら、貧しい人々を助けるために活動をしたいと思っています。
