examples.en: My vocabulary in Japanese is still quite poor.
examples.ja: 私の日本語のボキャブラリーはまだまだ貧しいです。

examples.en: Her life may be poor, but her heart is very rich. I find her much more likable than someone who is wealthy but poor in spirit.
examples.ja: 彼女のくらしは貧しいけれど、心はとても豊かです。お金持ちだけど心が貧しい人より、彼女の方がとても好感が持てます。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>poor</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>poor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You know the word 先ず (まず)? It means something along the lines of "first of all." So, if you're <vocabulary>poor</vocabulary>, <reading>first of all</reading> (まず), you're going to want to get some help. Second of all, learn how to play the guitar and make funny jokes.

examples.en: I was so poor as a student that I ate cup noodles every day.
examples.ja: 学生時代はずっと貧乏で、毎日カップラーメンばっかりだった。

examples.en: Being poor doesn't mean you have to give up on your dreams.
examples.ja: 貧乏だからといって、夢をあきらめる必要はありません。

examples.en: Poverty doesn't necessarily mean unhappiness.
examples.ja: 貧乏が必ずしも不幸を意味するわけではありません。

meaning_mnemonic: You are <kanji>poor</kanji> and money / food is very <kanji>scarce</kanji> for you, making you <vocabulary>poor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm considering purchasing new software.
examples.ja: 新しいソフトウェアの購入を検討しています。

examples.en: After purchasing, returns are only accepted if the item is unused.
examples.ja: 購入後の返品は、未使用の場合に限ります。

examples.en: Please be sure to get a receipt when making a purchase.
examples.ja: 購入の際には、必ず領収書を受け取ってください。

examples.en: This is the store where I bought the fake Chanel Number 5.
examples.ja: この店で偽のシャネルN°5を購入しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <kanji>purchase</kanji> <kanji>enter</kanji>s into effect, you have made your <vocabulary>purchase</vocabulary>.

購入 is a relatively formal word for the act of purchasing something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let’s create a new marketing strategy based on this purchasing data.
examples.ja: この購買データをもとに、新しいマーケティング戦略を立てましょう。

examples.en: My colleague who works at the purchasing department is my best friend.
examples.ja: 会社の購買部につとめている同僚は私の親友です。

examples.en: Buying bread at the school store is something I look forward to every day.
examples.ja: 学校の購買でパンを買うのが、毎日の楽しみなんだよね。

examples.en: I’m researching customer appetites.
examples.ja: 私は消費者の購買意欲について研究をしています。

meaning_mnemonic: You purchase and buy something? That's some serious purchasing. 購買 is a formal term for the act of purchasing goods or services, mostly in business or economic contexts. It's often combined with another word, like in 購買意欲 (consumer appetite) or 購買力 (purchasing power). In some contexts, 購買 can also refer to a school shop or campus store, especially in high schools or universities.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is on'yomi, which is great for 購 but not as great for 買. Luckily, the reading for 買 is <reading>buy</reading> (ばい), which is the same as the meaning, which is a pretty awesome coincidence.

examples.en: The number of subscribers to this online news site is increasing year by year.
examples.ja: このオンラインニュースサイトの購読者数は年々増加しています。

examples.en: I cancelled my subscription to a magazine, as I no longer read it.
examples.ja: 購読してた雑誌、読まなくなったから解約しちゃった。

examples.en: Get your subscription to the Tofugu Newspaper here!
examples.ja: トーフグ新聞の定期購読はこちらから！

examples.en: The rumor that all American people subscribe to the Tofugu newsletter spread throughout Japan.
examples.ja: 全アメリカ人がトーフグのニュースレターを購読しているという噂が、日本中に広まった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a <kanji>purchase</kanji>d <kanji>read</kanji> — especially one that comes regularly. In other words, a <vocabulary>subscription</vocabulary>.

購読 specifically refers to paying for a subscription to some kind of reading material, like a newspaper or magazine, so be sure not to use it for free subscriptions!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The on'yomi for 読 (どく) is the same as the reading in 読者. In case you forgot, think about how you just got a subscription to <reading>dock</reading> (どく) magazine. It's all about docks and dock related things. How exciting.

examples.en: It takes at least two hours to cross this mountain.
examples.ja: この山を越えるのに、二時間はかかります。

examples.en: The titans are coming over the wall!
examples.ja: 巨人がカベを越えてくるぞ！

examples.en: If you go straight for a while beyond this bridge, you will find a station.
examples.ja: この橋を越えてしばらく真っ直ぐ行くと、駅があります。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go beyond</kanji>, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to go beyond</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>To go beyond</vocabulary> <reading>child</reading> (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in both the USA and Japan.

examples.en: Isn't that overstepping your authority? You don't have the legal power to do that to begin with, right?
examples.ja: それは越権じゃないですか？そもそも法的権限がないですよね？

examples.en: I think even if it was taken as a sort of exceeding authority, we can't do anything about it.
examples.ja: それは、越権の一種だと思われても仕方が無いと思います。

examples.en: If you hold a position of power, it's important to clearly understand where the boundaries of overstepping your authority lie, as failing to do so can be dangerous.
examples.ja: 権力のある立場についたら、どこからが越権とみなされるのか、線引きをしっかり分かっておかないと危険ですよ。

examples.en: Officer, I'm afraid you are overstepping your bounds.
examples.ja: お巡りさん、差し出がましいようですがそれは越権行為では無いでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>go beyond</kanji> your <kanji>rights</kanji>, you are going too far. You're doing what you're not supposed to do, and you're overstepping your authority.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Why did you draw the butterfly upside down?
examples.ja: どうしてチョウチョを逆さまに描いたの？

examples.en: I got the directions wrong because the map was upside down.
examples.ja: 地図が逆さまだったので、進む方向を間違えました。

examples.en: Huh, isn't this text flipped left to right?
examples.ja: あれ、この文字、左右逆さまじゃない？

examples.en: On Viet's desk, Koichi's photo is displayed upside down.
examples.ja: ビエトのデスクには、コウイチの写真が上下逆さまで飾られています。

meaning_mnemonic: Something is <kanji>reverse</kanji>, that much you know. The さま comes from 様, which could mean <kanji>manner</kanji>. So, something that is in a "reverse manner," is something that is <vocabulary>upside down</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 逆らう and 様, put together. A bit of an <vocabulary>upside down</vocabulary> reading if I do say so myself, but you do what you gotta do.

examples.en: I don't have a single friend to play with.
examples.ja: 遊ぶ友達が一人もいないんです。

examples.en: We are just having fun with this game. Don't be so serious.
examples.ja: ゲームで楽しく遊んでるだけなのに、そうムキになるなよ。

examples.en: Wanna hang out at my place sometime?
examples.ja: 今度、俺んちで遊ばない？

examples.en: "You can't play outdoors until you finish your homework." "You don’t have to tell me, I know!"
examples.ja: 「宿題が済むまで、外で遊んじゃだめだからね。」「言われなくても分かってるよ！」

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>play</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to play</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You want <vocabulary>to play</vocabulary> with everyone, but every once in a while someone doesn't want to play with you. You know what? That's okay. If someone doesn't want to play with you, they're the <reading>a**hole</reading> (あそ), not you.

examples.en: This amusement park is popular as a dating spot.
examples.ja: この遊園地はデートスポットとして人気があります。

examples.en: I ate takoyaki at the amusement park food court.
examples.ja: 遊園地のフードコートでたこ焼きを食べました。

examples.en: That amusement park in Kobe is a nice place to go and play with little kids.
examples.ja: あの神戸の遊園地は、小さい子と遊びに行くにはいい所ですよ。

examples.en: "I am going to go skydiving then afterwards go to a theme park. You want to join me?" "What? Absolutely not!"
examples.ja: 「スカイダイビングをして、その後遊園地に行くんだけど、一緒に行かない？」「えーっ、絶対に嫌！」

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>play</kanji> <kanji>park</kanji> <kanji>ground</kanji> is where you go play. It's fun. It's an <vocabulary>amusement park</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please choose the appropriate answer.
examples.ja: 適当な答えを選んでください。

examples.en: That guy often says irresponsible things.
examples.ja: あいつは適当な事ばかり言っている。

examples.en: I was surprised when my colleague was ordering in an izakaya and said to the waitress: "Choose whatever you think is best".
examples.ja: 居酒屋で、同僚が店員に「適当にお願いします」と言って注文をしたことに驚きました。

meaning_mnemonic: Everything is <kanji>suitable</kanji> and <kanji>right</kanji>. Therefore it is <vocabulary>appropriate</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>proper</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>suitable</vocabulary>. Strangely enough, this also means <vocabulary>irresponsible</vocabulary>. Maybe it's because when everything is suitable and right for you, you're taking too much and not leaving enough for everyone else, making you irresponsible?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Everyone has things they are suited or unsuited for.
examples.ja: 人には適不適がある。

examples.en: In a positive sense, I think this job is unsuitable for you.
examples.ja: いい意味で、この仕事は君には不適だと思うよ。

examples.en: Someone who is too passive is not suitable as a marriage partner.
examples.ja: あまりにも受け身すぎる人は、結婚相手には不適です。

examples.en: I've been thinking about whether this job suits me or not, but I haven't found the answer yet.
examples.ja: この職が私にとって適不適かを考えているんですが、まだ答えは出ていません。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>suitable</kanji> is <vocabulary>unsuitable</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>inappropriate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You can register for free.
examples.ja: 無料で登録することができますよ。

examples.en: You need an email address to register a new account.
examples.ja: 新しいアカウントを登録するにはメールアドレスが必要です。

examples.en: Apparently, you get perks just by registering!
examples.ja: 登録するだけで特典がもらえるんだって！

examples.en: What motivated you to register yourself as an organ donor?
examples.ja: 臓器提供者として登録をしたきっかけは何ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: 登録 is <kanji>registration</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to register</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What? You deposited how much?
examples.ja: え？今、いくら預けたって言った？

examples.en: During your trip, you can leave your luggage at the hotel front desk.
examples.ja: 旅行中は荷物をホテルのフロントに預けることができます。

examples.en: I leave my kid at a nursery school during my work.
examples.ja: 仕事をしている間は子供は保育園に預けています。

examples.en: By depositing money in the bank, you can keep it safe.
examples.ja: 銀行にお金を預けることで、安全に管理することができます。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deposit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to deposit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to entrust</vocabulary>. 

You use 預ける when you leave something in someone else's care for a while, expecting to get it back. For example, you can use 預ける when you deposit money in a bank, leave your coat in a cloakroom, or even when you park your bicycle in a parking area. You can also use it when you leave your child with grandparents or leave your dog at a pet hotel.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

In terms of places where you want <vocabulary>to deposit</vocabulary> your money, the last place on your list should be <reading>a zoo</reading> (あず). I mean seriously, you know the animals are just gonna munch up all your dolla bills.

examples.en: I deposit part of my salary every month.
examples.ja: 私は給料の一部を毎月預金しています。

examples.en: You can check your bank balance at an ATM too.
examples.ja: 預金残高なら、ATMでも確認できますよ。

examples.en: Interest rates are higher for fixed deposits.
examples.ja: 利率は定期預金の方が高いです。

examples.en: He deposits all the money he earns from raising scallops.
examples.ja: 彼は帆立の養殖で稼いだ金は全て預金している。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Deposit</kanji> your <kanji>gold</kanji> here in the bank. When you do that, it is a <vocabulary>bank deposit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Decorating the living room with a painting really brightens up the space, huh?
examples.ja: リビングに絵を飾ると、部屋が明るくなりますね。

examples.en: Decorating the store entrance with balloons makes children happy.
examples.ja: 店の入り口を風船で飾ると、子供たちが喜びます。

examples.en: Decorating the classroom with crafts and other artworks can increase students' motivation.
examples.ja: 教室をクラフトの作品などで飾ることで、生徒たちのモチベーションが上がることがあります。

examples.en: I like decorating the Christmas tree. I put it beside our fireplace this year.
examples.ja: クリスマスツリーの飾り付けをするのが好きです。今年はツリーを暖炉の横に飾りました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decorate</kanji>. The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decorate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>To decorate</vocabulary> something, you don't really need a <reading>cause</reading> (かざ). You should just do it, just be<reading>cause</reading>.

examples.en: I graduated from a fashion technical school.
examples.ja: 私は服飾専門学校を卒業しました。

examples.en: I'm working in the clothing business now, mostly for fun.
examples.ja: 今の服飾の仕事は、遊び半分でしてるんですよ。

examples.en: That guy's dating a fashion student.
examples.ja: コイツ、今、服飾の専門学生と付き合ってるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>clothes</kanji> with which I <kanji>decorate</kanji> myself with is my <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary> or my <vocabulary>fashion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The decorative lights on that truck were so sparkly and beautiful!
examples.ja: あのトラックの電飾、すごくキラキラしててきれいだったよ！

examples.en: A project in which they will make a fugu-shaped decorative lighting sign is now underway at Tofugu.
examples.ja: トーフグでは今、フグ型の電飾看板を作るプロジェクトが持ち上がっています。

examples.en: Koichi and Viet compete against each other by decorating with lights around their houses during the Christmas season.
examples.ja: コウイチとビエトはクリスマスシーズン中、家の周りを電飾で飾って競い合います。

examples.en: I heard that you use power strips for decorative lighting to eliminate wasted energy, but you might overload the circuits so it's dangerous.
examples.ja: 省エネのために電飾にOAタップを使ってるって聞いたんだけど、タコ足配線にするのは危ないわよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The 電 is what powers electric things. Many times, these electric things light up (especially back in the day, when electricity did this a lot more than other things). So, you have "lighting." Then, you have <kanji>decorate</kanji>. So, if you decorate with lighting, you have <vocabulary>decorative lighting</vocabulary>.

This is quite a specific word that is generally used as a product category for decorative lighting. It’s a less common word than other expressions, such as デコレーションライト or イルミネーションライト.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please be quiet in the hospital. Making noise is an annoyance to others.
examples.ja: 病院では静かにしてください。騒ぐと他の人に迷惑です。

examples.en: To get my child to stop making noise, I had them watch YouTube on a smartphone.
examples.ja: 子どもが騒ぐのを止めさせるために、スマホでYouTubeを観せました。

examples.en: Someone was being noisy late at night, and the police were called.
examples.ja: 深夜に騒ぐ人がいて、警察が呼ばれました。

examples.en: Don't make so much noise! Do you wanna be killed? If not, just shut up.
examples.ja: 騒ぐな！死にたいのか？死にたくなけりゃ黙ってろ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>boisterous</kanji>. The verb version is <vocabulary>to make noise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be boisterous</vocabulary>. Basically, you're being boisterous when you make a lot of noise, so that's where it comes from.
reading_mnemonic: You're always going <vocabulary>to make noise</vocabulary> and be boisterous when you eat something <reading>sour</reading> (さわ). Imagine stuffing lemon slices, sour candy, and umeboshi into your mouth. All at once. See how much noise you make? They're so sour, and they make you so boisterous.

examples.en: This area is under construction so there is a lot of noise every day.
examples.ja: この辺は工事中で毎日騒音がすごいです。

examples.en: Noise is also one form of pollution.
examples.ja: 騒音も公害の一つです。

examples.en: Once you get used to noise, it can strangely become calming.
examples.ja: 騒音に慣れてしまうと、それが逆に落ち着くこともあります。

examples.en: How should I approach my neighbor about a noise problem?
examples.ja: 騒音問題について、お隣さんにどうやって切り出したらいいんだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Boisterous</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> is when there's a lot of <vocabulary>noise</vocabulary> around you. It's the <vocabulary>din</vocabulary> of the crowd or environment.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: A plan to attack the enemy base is underway.
examples.ja: 敵の基地を攻撃する計画が進行中だ。

examples.en: They were suddenly attacked just before dawn.
examples.ja: 彼らは夜明け前に突然攻撃された。

examples.en: It is not good to attack individuals during a discussion. Let's focus on ideas.
examples.ja: 議論中に、個人を攻撃するのは良くないですよ。アイディアに集中しましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: 攻撃 is an <kanji>attack</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 攻撃 as well.

examples.en: Oh, we met earlier at the convenience store too, didn't we?
examples.ja: あれ、先程コンビニでもお会いしましたよね？

examples.en: Who is the old man sitting over there from a little while ago?
examples.ja: 先程からあそこに座っているご老人はだれですか。

examples.en: As I told you earlier, your reservation was cancelled.
examples.ja: 先程も申しましたように、お客様の予約はキャンセルされました。

examples.en: I read the letter from you earlier today.
examples.ja: 先程あなたからの手紙を読ませて頂きました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>extent</kanji> of time was <vocabulary>a little while ago</vocabulary>. Just think to a previous extent of time that was indeed a little while ago. Now, associate!

先程 is limited to a relatively brief time frame within the same day. So it can be used for something mentioned earlier in a speech or at an event from <vocabulary>earlier in the day</vocabulary>, but not for something from a few days ago. 先程 is also polite and formal, so it's generally used in professional or respectful settings.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the words 先 and 程, put together.

examples.en: His bureaucratic way of speaking annoyed me a little.
examples.ja: 彼の官僚的な話し方に、少しイラっとしました。

examples.en: Many people get frustrated dealing with bureaucratic red tape.
examples.ja: 官僚的なたらい回しにあって、イライラする人は多い。

examples.en: There are too many bureaucratic processes in the world.
examples.ja: 世の中には官僚的なプロセスが多すぎます。

examples.en: There's too much bureaucratic red tape in this company.
examples.ja: この会社では官僚的な形式主義がまかり通りすぎている。

meaning_mnemonic: If 官僚 is "bureaucracy," then adding a 的 to it would make it <vocabulary>bureaucratic</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 官僚 will help a lot too.

examples.en: I heard that my grandpa used to be the prime minister.
examples.ja: ぼくのおじいちゃんは昔、総理大臣だったんだって。

examples.en: After a forty-year career in politics, I finally became prime minister.
examples.ja: 政治家のキャリア40年にしてようやく総理大臣にまで登りつめました。

examples.en: Hey y’all. Prime Minister Koichi is in da house, yo! Check it out!
examples.ja: よぉみんな！コウイチ総理大臣がここに登場だぜ！チェケラ！

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>whole</kanji> <kanji>reason</kanji> our country is still running is because of our "minister" (大臣). Which minister? The <vocabulary>prime minister</vocabulary>, of course. Without our prime minister, we'd all be doomed I say. DOOMED!

Unlike 首相, which can be used for any prime minister, this word is used only for the <vocabulary>Japanese prime minister</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It also contains a vocab word you've learned recently, 大臣!

examples.en: I'll be transferring to a new department starting next month.
examples.ja: 来月から新しい部署に移ることになりました。

examples.en: Now, let's shift to the next discussion.
examples.ja: それでは、次の話題に移りましょう。

examples.en: I haven't been able to make even one friend since I relocated to this town.
examples.ja: この町に移ってきてからまだ友達が一人もできません。

examples.en: I don't like yakiniku because the smell gets on your clothes.
examples.ja: においが服に移るから、焼肉は好きじゃないの。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shift</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be shifted</vocabulary>. You know that this is the one where something is shifted (and you're not doing the shifting), because it's really <reading>ru</reading>de (る) to be shifted, and you don't like it when people do it to you (because it happens quite a lot, strangely).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 移す, so use that to remember this!

examples.en: My dog is afraid of thunder.
examples.ja: うちの犬はカミナリを怖がるんだ。

examples.en: I can't watch horror movies at home because my sister gets scared.
examples.ja: ホラー映画は妹が怖がるから、家では観れないんだよね。

examples.en: Many people are afraid of it, but that insect is actually harmless.
examples.ja: 怖がる人が多いけど、実はその虫は無害なんですよ。

examples.en: My husband was very scared of getting surgery for his ingrown eyelashes.
examples.ja: 私の主人は逆さ睫毛の手術を受けるのをとても怖がっていたんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: 怖い is "scary." This is a verb version, making it <vocabulary>to be scared</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be afraid of</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 怖い.

examples.en: I am the owner of that wallet.
examples.ja: そのサイフの持ち主は私です。

examples.en: Did you find the owner who’d lost it?
examples.ja: 落とし主は見つかりましたか？

examples.en: I recognized the owner of the voice easily, even without seeing his face.
examples.ja: 顔を見なくても、声の主はすぐ分かりました。

examples.en: This pond is home to a large tree frog called the Lord of the Old Pond.
examples.ja: この池には、古池の主と呼ばれる大きなトノサマガエルが住んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>master</kanji> is the <vocabulary>owner</vocabulary> who has dominance or control over something.

主 is usually used with other words to indicate a person who owns something or who is principally involved in an action. That might sound a little vague, so check out the collocations and context sentences to get a better grasp of this word!
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this:

The <vocabulary>owner</vocabulary> of those <reading>nu</reading>de <reading>shee</reading>p (ぬし) doesn’t even need their wool, he just likes owning nude sheep. So he keeps them as pets and shaves them every day. He’s not interested in sheep with fur. Only nude sheep for this owner!

examples.en: The snow piled up thirty centimeters deep last night and my car got buried.
examples.ja: 昨夜、雪が30cmも積もり、車が埋もれてしまいました。

examples.en: My friend's LINE message got buried in my notifications, so I didn't notice!
examples.ja: 友達からのLINE、通知に埋もれてて、気づかなかった！

examples.en: We have to work hard to keep his talent from being buried!
examples.ja: アイツの才能が埋もれてしまわないように、俺たちが頑張らないと！

examples.en: My brother's room was always overflowing with stuff, and important things often ended up buried somewhere in there.
examples.ja: 兄の部屋はいつも色んなものにあふれていて、大事なものがどこかに埋もれるのはよくあることだった。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that 埋まる is "to be buried." This verb is also <vocabulary>to be buried</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get buried</vocabulary>. 

However, there's a slight difference between them. 埋まる focuses on the subject itself getting buried or filled, while 埋もれる highlights the sense of something being hidden or obscured by being covered. So you could use it to describe a yard covered in snow or your talent being overshadowed in a competitive environment. 

You can remember this nuance because it's <reading>more rare</reading> (もれる) to see something completely buried and covered up.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 埋める.

examples.en: In horror movies, the "something's behind you" trope is the most terrifying.
examples.ja: ホラー映画で、背後に何かいるパターンが一番怖い！

examples.en: Hey! Don't talk to me suddenly from behind, you startled me!
examples.ja: ちょっと！背後から急に話しかけないで、びっくりするから！

examples.en: On these stairs, red pandas might attack you. So please be cautious of what's behind you.
examples.ja: この階段では、レッサーパンダがおそってくることがあるんで、背後に注意してくださいね。

examples.en: I completely didn't notice the enemy lurking in the background.
examples.ja: 背後に敵が潜んでいたことに全く気づかなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>behind</kanji> your <kanji>back</kanji> is in the <vocabulary>background</vocabulary>. It's also probably plotting against you, <vocabulary>behind the scenes</vocabulary>. Sneaky, sneaky.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

examples.en: When I started living alone in my twenties, I discovered the pleasure of eating junk food.
examples.ja: 20代のころに一人ぐらしを始めて、ジャンクフードを食べる快楽に目覚めてしまったんです。

examples.en: Learning kanji on WaniKani has become so enjoyable that I've turned into a kanji learning junkie, with my brain flooded with pleasure chemicals.
examples.ja: ワニカニで漢字をどんどん覚えるのが楽しすぎて、脳内快楽物質ドバドバの漢字学習ジャンキーになってしまった。

examples.en: Why does evil continue to exist in the world? It's because people can get used to pleasure, but never to pain. Thus everyone defines as evil whatever causes them pain.
examples.ja: なぜ世界には悪が存在し続けるのかって？それは、人は快楽には慣れるが、苦痛には一生慣れないからだよ。そして、みんな、自分が苦痛を感じるものを悪だと定義するからさ。

examples.en: I was close to drowning in pleasure.
examples.ja: もう少しで、快楽に溺れるところだったわ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Pleasant</kanji> <kanji>comfort</kanji> brings you a lot of <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary>.

快楽 is more commonly used in writing and often describes pleasure with a sense of indulgence, especially physical or sensory pleasure.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Life with an air conditioner is pleasant.
examples.ja: エアコンのある生活は快適だ。

examples.en: The bullet train yesterday was empty, and it was so comfortable!
examples.ja: 昨日の新幹線はガラガラで、めっちゃ快適だったよ！

examples.en: I set up a comfortable workspace for remote work.
examples.ja: リモートワークするのに快適な作業スペースを作りました。

examples.en: This app is easy to use, so you can comfortably continue your work.
examples.ja: このアプリは使いやすくて、快適に作業が進められます。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is both <kanji>pleasant</kanji> and <kanji>suitable</kanji> is still really <vocabulary>pleasant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I understand, so that was the reason.
examples.ja: 成程、そういう理由だったんですね。

examples.en: I see, I didn't know that. I learned something new.
examples.ja: 成程、それは知りませんでした。勉強になりました。

examples.en: I see! I can send this letter without anyone finding out.
examples.ja: 成程、これなら誰にも見つからずに手紙を出すことができる。

examples.en: Indeed, Viet was also good at shooting birds.
examples.ja: 成程、ビエトは鳥を撃つのも上手かった。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>become</kanji> aware of something to an <kanji>extent</kanji> you'll end up saying <vocabulary>I see</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>that makes sense</vocabulary>! But you won't see if you didn't become aware enough. So it's that extent of understanding you're trying to reach before you can chime in with an "Ahh, <vocabulary>indeed</vocabulary>."

成程 is a common expression used to acknowledge understanding or express agreement with something that's just been explained to you. It can be used in both formal and informal conversations. Just keep in mind this word is usually written in kana!
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. The reading for 成 is from 成る and it keeps the る part. It's just hidden in the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll know this reading!

examples.en: I'm weak-willed to pressure.
examples.ja: 俺は押しに弱いんだよなあ。

examples.en: My last girlfriend was too pushy and we broke up after two weeks.
examples.ja: 前の彼女は押しが強すぎて二週間で別れてしまった。

examples.en: In negotiations, balancing push and pull is important.
examples.ja: 交渉においては、押しと引きのバランスが重要です。

examples.en: I gave in to his "Just one more drink!" pressure and ended up drinking too much.
examples.ja: 彼の「もう一杯！」という押しに負けて、飲みすぎちゃいました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Mix the ground meat well.
examples.ja: ひき肉を程よくこねます。

examples.en: Adding just the right amount of salt enhances the flavor of a dish.
examples.ja: 料理に塩を程よく加えると、味が引き立ちます。

examples.en: Properly cutting corners is the key to working long-term.
examples.ja: 程よく手を抜くことも、仕事を長く続けるコツだよ。

examples.en: For your health, it's important to exercise moderately.
examples.ja: 健康のためには、程よく運動を続けることが大切です。

meaning_mnemonic: If the <kanji>extent</kanji> you go to do something is properly (よく) done, then you did it <vocabulary>properly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Nice!

examples.en: This perfume doesn't smell at all.
examples.ja: この香水は、全く匂わない。

examples.en: Ugh, something smells in this room!
examples.ja: げ、なんかこの部屋、匂う！

examples.en: Hmm, something smells. It smells like a case, Watson!
examples.ja: フーム、匂いますねー。事件の匂いがしますよ、ワトソン君！

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>smell</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to smell</vocabulary>.

Although 匂う is technically a neutral term, it often means <vocabulary>to smell bad</vocabulary>. To emphasize the stinkiness, you can also use the kanji 臭 instead of 匂.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: It's good to wet your hair before shampooing.
examples.ja: 髪をよく濡らしてから、シャンプーをするといいですよ。

examples.en: This USB is important, so please be careful not to get it wet with coffee or water.
examples.ja: 大事なUSBなので、コーヒーや水で濡らさないで下さいね。

examples.en: Since I was dumped by my senpai, every day I've been soaking my pillow with tears.
examples.ja: 先輩にフラれてから、毎日涙で枕を濡らしています。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wet</kanji> or <kanji>damp</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to wet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dampen</vocabulary> something.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: I moved the toys close to the wall.
examples.ja: オモチャをカベに寄せた。

examples.en: I pulled the car over and parked.
examples.ja: 車をワキに寄せて停めた。

examples.en: All kinds of comments were posted on this podcast episode.
examples.ja: このポッドキャストには色んなコメントが寄せられた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. The kanji itself means <kanji>draw near</kanji>, and the verb version is about making or letting something draw near to something else. That's why it means <vocabulary>to move something close to</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to pull something over</vocabulary>, and also <vocabulary>to contribute something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You want <vocabulary>to move something close to</vocabulary> you, but it's out of reach. The solution, of course, is to take out your trusty <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ) and lasso that thing and pull it closer!

examples.en: This charm has the power to repel misfortune.
examples.ja: このお守りには、災いを退ける力がある。

examples.en: The council dismissed all of the proposals.
examples.ja: 議会は全ての議案を退けた。

examples.en: It's hard for Japan to reject the opinions of the U.S.
examples.ja: 日本にとってアメリカの意見を退けることは難しい。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>retreat</kanji>, and this verb version is when you make something retreat. In other words, it means <vocabulary>to repel something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to dismiss something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to reject something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You repel something, like bad luck. You reject something, like a proposal.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this with its intransitive pair verb 退く, but here's a mnemonic just in case:

Remember the re-zoner? Well, <vocabulary>to repel</vocabulary> bad luck, <reading>she, re-zo</reading>ned (しりぞ) the whole place. No bad luck allowed inside the zone.

examples.en: Playing games too much will hurt your eyes.
examples.ja: ゲームのやりすぎは目を痛める。

examples.en: I ran a full marathon in slippers and injured my ankles.
examples.ja: スリッパでフルマラソンをしたら足首を痛めた。

examples.en: That incident is still breaking mom's heart.
examples.ja: 母は今でもそのことで心を痛めている。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>pain</kanji>, and this verb is transitive, so it means to inflict pain. In other words, it's <vocabulary>to injure something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to hurt someone</vocabulary>.

This verb focuses on the pain involved in an injury, so it can only be used for things that feel pain, like people and body parts.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the word 痛い.

examples.en: My leg got stuck in the fence and I can't get it out.
examples.ja: 柵に足がはさまって抜けない。

examples.en: I'll paint the fence this afternoon.
examples.ja: 今日の午後は柵をペンキでぬります。

examples.en: That dog jumped over the fence so easily.
examples.ja: その犬は柵を軽々と跳び越えてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Isn't that fencetastic?
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Just think about the <reading>sack</reading> (さく) hanging on the <vocabulary>fence</vocabulary>.

examples.en: How do you feel about enclosing that with an iron fence?
examples.ja: そこに鉄柵をめぐらすのはどうでしょう。

examples.en: I have to repair the iron fence as soon as possible.
examples.ja: 出来るだけ早く鉄柵を修理しないといけません。

examples.en: Look! Something's caught on the iron fence.
examples.ja: 見て！鉄柵に何か引っかかっているよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Ready for this one? An <kanji>iron</kanji> <kanji>fence </kanji> is an <vocabulary>iron fence</vocabulary>. Don't you love it when it's straightforward?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful though, 鉄 is normally read as てつ, but in this case it is shortened to てっ.

examples.en: More and more fields are surrounded by electric fences.
examples.ja: 電気柵を張りめぐらせる畑が増えている。

examples.en: My dad installed the electric fence.
examples.ja: お父さんが電気柵を設置してくれたんです。

examples.en: We've installed electric fences as a countermeasure against wild boars and monkeys.
examples.ja: イノシシや猿への対策として、電気柵を導入した。

meaning_mnemonic: If you combine 電気 (electricity) with 柵 (<kanji>fence</kanji>) you have an <vocabulary>electric fence</vocabulary>. Shocking, I know.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Today's dinner at our house is deep-fried shrimp.
examples.ja: 我が家の今日のディナーはエビフライです。

examples.en: In the end, everyone loves their own child the most.
examples.ja: だれだって、結局我が子が一番可愛いんだよ。

examples.en: The section chief was saying exactly what you said, as if it were his own words.
examples.ja: 課長、あんたの受け売りをそのまま、我が物顔で言ってたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Here we have <kanji>I</kanji> followed by the particle が, giving us a somewhat old-fashioned and stylized way of say <vocabulary>our</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>one's own</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>my</vocabulary>.

One explanation for this is that in ancient Japanese, が was used as a possessive particle, much like の is in modern Japanese.
reading_mnemonic:
You haven't learned this reading for 我 so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Let us present you with <vocabulary>our</vocabulary> <reading>wa</reading>lrus (わ). Well it's <vocabulary>my</vocabulary> walrus really, but I'm happy to share.

examples.en: The alien held down the man's head forcefully with his left hand.
examples.ja: 宇宙人は左手でガッと男の頭を押さえた。

examples.en: These words are important, so make sure to master them!
examples.ja: この単語は大事なので、しっかり押さえておきましょう！

examples.en: What's wrong? You're holding your stomach.
examples.ja: どうしたの、お腹押さえて。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>push</kanji>, and this verb means things like <vocabulary>to hold something down</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to grasp something</vocabulary>. This verb is pretty versatile, and you can use it if you're holding down a piece of paper, holding a cloth to a wound, or grasping a concept.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so hopefully you can read this on your own.

examples.en: This place is a tonkotsu ramen restaurant.
examples.ja: ここは豚骨ラーメンの店です。

examples.en: This pork bone ramen makes me feel nostalgic.
examples.ja: この豚骨ラーメンを食べると懐かしい気持ちになるよ。

examples.en: By all means, please come to Kyushu to eat tonkotsu ramen.
examples.ja: 是非、九州に豚骨ラーメンを食べに来て下さい。

meaning_mnemonic: Pig bone ramen is tonkotsu ramen or, very logically indeed, pork bone ramen. 豚骨ラーメン is a type of Japanese ramen made with a rich, creamy broth from 豚骨 (pork bones). The bones are simmered for hours to extract the flavors, resulting in a flavorful and hearty soup. It's so delicious, you'll be back for more. Bone appetit!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know both of these readings, but in case you need a reminder, here's a mnemonic to help you out:

You really like <vocabulary>tonkotsu ramen</vocabulary> so you just ate a whole <reading>ton</reading> (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of <vocabulary>pork bone ramen</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Every joint in my body is throbbing somehow.
examples.ja: なんか体の節々がズキズキする。

examples.en: That person makes some harsh word choices, huh?
examples.ja: あの人、言葉の節々にトゲがあるよね。

examples.en: Saori woke up with pains in various joints.
examples.ja: 早織は節々の痛みを感じて目を覚ました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>joint</kanji> <kanji>joint</kanji>s are your <vocabulary>various joints</vocabulary>, or even <vocabulary>every joint</vocabulary> in your body, or a specific body part. When we're not talking about the joints in your body, this means something like <vocabulary>various parts</vocabulary>, referring to various parts of a whole.
reading_mnemonic: This is just the kun'yomi of 節, which you learned with 節目, repeated twice. Keep in mind that the second ふし gets rendaku'd to ぶし!

examples.en: Apparently, an overnight stay with a breakfast buffet costs 5,000 yen at this hotel.
examples.ja: このホテル、朝食バイキング付きで五千円だって。

examples.en: Would you like to go to an all-you-can-eat cake place with me sometime?
examples.ja: 今度いっしょにケーキバイキングに行かない？

examples.en: The Christmas party will be buffet style.
examples.ja: クリスマスパーティーは、バイキング形式にする予定だよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
バイキング comes from the English word <vocabulary>Viking</vocabulary>, but in Japanese, it often refers to a <vocabulary>buffet</vocabulary>.

バイキング came to mean "buffet" thanks to Japan’s first all-you-can-eat restaurant, "Viking", which was named after a feast scene from a movie called (you guessed it) "Viking".

examples.en: Oh no, I forgot to arrange the documents for the meeting.
examples.ja: しまった、会議の書類を揃えるのを忘れてた。

examples.en: All my kitchen supplies are from the same manufacturer.
examples.ja: キッチン用品は全部同じメーカーで揃えてるんです。

examples.en: Everyone was saying in unison that he is not at fault.
examples.ja: みんな口を揃えてアイツは悪くないって言ってたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember 揃う, "to be complete"? This is the transitive version of that, and it means things like <vocabulary>to arrange something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to gather something</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to align something</vocabulary>.

This one is a little tricky to understand and translate well. At its core, this verb describes the act of arranging all of the necessary things for something. But it can also describe aligning certain things in a uniform, matching manner. If this still isn't clear, have a careful look at our context sentences and collocations!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already know this, so you're all good here!

examples.en: I ordered a single commercial-grade iron plate.
examples.ja: 業務用の鉄板を一枚注文した。

examples.en: I enjoy gathering around a teppan grill with everyone and eating okonomiyaki.
examples.ja: みんなで鉄板を囲んでお好み焼きを食べるのが好きだ。

examples.en: This is one of my surefire jokes.
examples.ja: これ、オレの鉄板ネタなんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Well, you've got <kanji>iron</kanji> and you've got a <kanji>board</kanji>. You'd probably just call it an <vocabulary>iron plate</vocabulary>, though. But this often isn't just any iron plate. If you could guess from the reading, it's often used in cooking as an <vocabulary>iron griddle</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>teppan grill</vocabulary>. Ever heard of Teppanyaki?

Figuratively, it means a <vocabulary>sure thing</vocabulary> or a practically guaranteed success. For example, you can use 鉄板 for a racehorse almost certain to win, or a joke that consistently gets big laughs.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku and you should be good!

examples.en: I have a five-year-old niece.
examples.ja: 私には五才の姪がいます。

examples.en: I love my niece very much.
examples.ja: 私は姪っ子が大好きです。

examples.en: I met my niece's husband for the first time the other day.
examples.ja: 先日、姪の夫に初めて会いました。

examples.en: Oh, sorry it's so confusing. My niece's child's name is Mei.
examples.ja: あっ、ややこしくてすいません。私の姪の子供の名前がメイなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This is just the kanji <kanji>niece</kanji> as a vocab, so this also means <vocabulary>niece</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: As a standalone vocab, this uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, that's what you learned with the kanji, so no new reading here!
